headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to the First Quarter 2016 Hewlett-Packard Enterprise Earnings Conference Call. My name is Laura, and I will be your conference moderator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to the First Quarter 2016 Hewlett-Packard Enterprise Earnings Conference Call. My name is Laura, and I will be your conference moderator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes. 
I would now like to turn the presentation over to your host for today's call, Mr. Andrew Simanek, Head of Investor Relations. Please proceed.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. I'm Andy Simanek, Head of Investor Relations to Hewlett-Packard Enterprise, and I'd like to welcome you to our Fiscal 2016 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call with Meg Whitman, HPE's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Tim Stonec
componenttext:
Good afternoon. I'm Andy Simanek, Head of Investor Relations to Hewlett-Packard Enterprise, and I'd like to welcome you to our Fiscal 2016 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call with Meg Whitman, HPE's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Tim Stonecipher, HPE's Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
Before handing the call over to Meg, let me remind you that this call is being webcast. A replay of the webcast will be made available shortly after the call for approximately one year. We posted the press release and the slide presentation accompanying today's earnings release on our HPE Investor Relations web page at investors.hpe.com. 
As always, elements of this presentation are forward-looking and are based on our best view of the world and our businesses as we see them today. For more detailed information, please see the disclaimers on the earnings materials relating to forward-looking statements that involve risks, uncertainties and assumptions. For a discussion of some of these risks, uncertainties and assumptions, please refer to HPE's SEC reports, including its most recent Form 10-K. 
HPE assumes no obligation and does not intend to update any such forward-looking statements. We also note that the financial information discussed on this call reflects estimates based on information available at this time, and could differ materially from the amounts ultimately reported in HPE's quarterly report on Form 10-Q for the fiscal quarter ended January 31, 2016. 
Finally, for financial information that has been expressed on a non-GAAP basis, we have included reconciliations to the comparable GAAP information. Please refer to the tables and slide presentation accompanying today's earnings release. 
With that, let me turn it over to Meg.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andy. Good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for joining us today. We've now completed our first full quarter as an independent company and we're off to a very strong start. We are already seeing the benefits of being a smaller, more focused and agil
componenttext:
Thanks, Andy. Good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for joining us today. We've now completed our first full quarter as an independent company and we're off to a very strong start. We are already seeing the benefits of being a smaller, more focused and agile company across a number of fronts. Our customers and partners understand our strategy and appreciate working with the simplified faster moving organization. Our employees are engaged and aligned. 
For example, we've created a single pan HPA sales training and account planning program, which has already uncovered over 100 accounts where there are significant untapped cross-selling opportunities. Our innovation engine is firing on all cylinders and you're going to see some amazing new introductions in the coming quarters in key areas of the portfolio, including servers, cloud, high performance computing, IoT, all flash storage, Aruba and converge systems. 
For our shareholders, this focus is driving strong financial and operational performance. In Q1, we delivered our third consecutive quarter of growth in constant currency with revenue of $12.7 billion up 4% year-over-year. And when you exclude the impact from recent M&A activities, we grew revenue on a constant currency basis in every 1 of our business segments for the first time since Q4 fiscal year '10. 
At the same time, we continue to make progress on our cost structure particularly in ES and delivered non-GAAP diluted net earnings per share of $0.41 at the top end of our previously provided range. Delivering strong cash flow is also a key priority for us. While Q1 was impacted by seasonality, separation payments and timing, we expect cash flow to improve as we move through the year and remained confident in our full year free cash flow outlook of $2 billion to $2.2 billion. 
Tim will walk through the specific Q1 cash flow drivers in a minute. Finally, in line with our commitment to return cash to our shareholders, in Q1, we paid $1.3 billion, including $1.2 billion for share repurchases and nearly $100 million in dividends. As a result, we've already exceeded our FY '16 commitment of returning at least 50% of expected free cash flow to shareholders. And share repurchases will remain our preferred method to return cash to shareholders given the current market conditions. Overall, while there is more work to do to accelerate top line growth, align our cost structure and drive even closer collaboration and integration across our organization, I'm very pleased with where we stand today. 
Now let me turn to business performance. We had another strong quarter in Enterprise Group with revenue up 7% year-over-year in constant currency. Our portfolio is truly the best we've had in years and is driving strong customer traction. For example, today, HPE is the leading infrastructure provider for SAP Hana with nearly twice the number of shipments over the next competitor. And this quarter, we won a number of important deals, including 1 with Canadian communications company, Rogers, to help them transform their existing traditional IT to a hybrid infrastructure. We will provide a comprehensive solution, including converge systems, cloud systems, StoreOnce pre-part all flash and technology services.
We also signed a multiyear agreement with one of the world's largest food producers, JBS to help them build an IT environment that supports faster business expansion, including consolidating their data centers and moving to the cloud. And just last week, at Mobile Word Congress, we announced that Swiss Com, Switzerland's leading telecommunications provider will deploy new virtual network functions using HPE open NFE solutions. 
This customer momentum is driving financial results and each of our hardware business units performed well in Q1. In servers, we delivered 5% year-over-year revenue growth in constant currency, maintain strong margins and also continued to make R&D investments. While we won't chase share for shares' sake, we continue to see significant growth opportunities ahead as the clear market leader with the most comprehensive portfolio of offerings, our mission-critical and High Performance Computing to our new IoT and cloud line solutions. 
Storage had another strong quarter with revenue up 3% year-over-year in constant currency, driven by continued strength in 3PAR. Converge storage grew 70% year-over-year and constant currency and is now a solid 56% of storage revenue. We had record revenue for 3PAR, driven by triple digit constant currency growth in all flash, which grew at a 3x the market rate. With the industry-leading all flash product and the broadest reach through our channel, we expect to gain share for the ninth quarter in a row in calendar Q4. 
Turning to networking. The significant actions we took last year are paying off and we are very pleased with the performance overall. Networking revenue grew 62% year-over-year in constant currency. Normalized for the Aruba acquisition, revenue grew double-digits, driven by record China revenue as well as good performance in other regions. As we've discussed before, we are seeing strength in China as customers anticipate the completion of the deal with Tsinghua, that we announced last year. 
We are currently working through the final regulatory approval in China and we expect the deal to close by the end of May. Aruba also grew double-digits at an operational level and we saw strong pull through of HPE's switching portfolio to compliment Aruba's wireless offerings. Technology Services revenue was down 3% in constant currency although TS support performed better. Total orders grew year-over-year, excluding China where we are seeing some customers delaying renewals until the Tsinghua transaction closed. 
Unlike networking or servers, these are long-term contracts and we believe some customers are waiting to work directly with the new entity. We also saw constant currency double-digit order growth in new solutions like Data Center Care and Proactive Care. We expect TS performance to improve throughout the year, driven by a better mix of new, faster growing support solutions. 
In cloud, following a major wave of product releases across our HPE Helion portfolio in the second half of 2015, we are seeing strong customer traction. In fact, since separation, Helion has gained over 200 customer wins, including some of the world's largest banks, service providers and industrials. This momentum reinforces our belief that our strategy of helping customers transform to a hybrid infrastructure is a winning approach for us. 
Enterprise Services continues to execute well against its turnaround strategy. ES is essence building a more diversified customer base, stabilizing revenue and significantly reducing its cost structure. For example, during the quarter, we grew new business TCV by 4% year-over-year in constant currency. This includes an agreement with Saber to provide virtualization, automation and security services, hardware and software to support faster product development and extend Saber's position in the global travel industry. And it includes an agreement with Avon to transform key elements of the leading beauty companies global IT infrastructure by offering a dedicated data center services, cross functional support, network management and security services. 
This builds on the progress we've made over the past 3 years. Remember that in FY '13, just 3 customers made up approximately 65% of ES operating profit. Today, no account makes up more than 10%. We also continued to make progress on our cost structure by exiting high cost data centers, improving low-cost location mix and rebalancing our workforce. As a result, Q1 revenue grew slightly in constant currency, marking the first quarter with constant currency growth since Q3 of '12. 
We also had our seventh consecutive quarter of year-over-year margin expansion. Q1 operating margin of 5.1% improved 2.1 points year-over-year driven largely by delivery cost actions. Overall, I believe we are taking the right steps to achieve our long-term goal of a sustainable market competitive cost structure with a 7% to 9% operating profit margin. In software, we continue to make progress, aligning the portfolio and go to market to our 4 transformation areas, increasing efficiency and accelerating fast. 
This has included the divestiture of several software businesses that were not core to our strategy, including iManage, Live Vault and Tipping Point, which we expect to close later this month. In Q1, software returned to growth with revenue up 1% in constant currency when adjusted for recent M&A activity. The ADM iTom business was down slightly in current currency as continued headwinds in license and support were nearly offset by professional services and record revenue growth in SaaS, which grew over 20% year-on-year. Big Data was strong with revenue up double-digits when normalized for currency and divestitures, driven by triple digit growth in vertical license. 
Security performance was also strong across both license and SaaS. Financial services continues to provide our customers with the financing the flexibility they need to take on their biggest IT challenges. At the same time, the team does a great job managing this business to minimize our risk and maximize our return. Financial services revenue grew 3% in constant currency in Q1 and financing volume also increased 3% year-over-year. 
Before I hand it over to Tim to provide further insight into the financials, I want to highlight some of the exciting product announcements for the quarter. One of the most important benefits from being a smaller more focused companies we're able to be very targeted in our investments and to even more effectively put our resources towards the most important, high-potential opportunities that support our strategy. As we discussed before, we prioritize organic investments to maintain a strong technology pipeline. At Discover in December, we unveiled HPE Synergy, a new category of infrastructure designed to learn both traditional and cloud native applications for organizations running a hybrid infrastructure. 
Synergy, powered by our 1D [ph] software, represents a critical step in delivering our vision for hybrid infrastructure. We also introduced our new IoT lite systems and we have a networking centers specifically designed to help customers more specifically collect, process and analyze IoT data. The new solutions are key elements of our strategy of delivering more strategy and computing power at the network edge and you can expect more IoT announcements coming up this year. 
And in January, HP expanded its network function virtualization portfolio. We announced HPE Service Director, a new end-to-end service operation solution designed to help communication service providers manage services in NFC by bridging traditional and new virtualized environments. In addition to organic investments, we are also investing in key partnerships. In January, HP and Skala announced an enhanced partnership designed to accelerate the adoption of software-defined storage. And we announced a new partnership with Microsoft appointing Asher as a preferred public cloud partner for HPE customers. While HPE now serves as a preferred partner in providing infrastructure and services for Microsoft's hybrid cloud offerings.
As a result of this commitment to innovation, our products and services are being recognized as leaders in the industry. For example, we are now named a leader in 26 different Gartner Magic Quadrants, including Integrated Systems, Modular Servers, Storage Disk Arrays and Wired and Wireless infrastructure. Forrester has ranked Enterprise Services as a leader in workplace services and positioned HPE as a leader in its recent private cloud report and IDC ranked us a the leader in application modernization services. Looking forward, you can expect this momentum and investment and innovation to continue. Later this month we will announce a new market changing hyper converged offering basin our industry-leading ProLiant virtualization server. 
Our new solution will offer customers installation in minutes, a consumer-inspired, simple, mobile-ready user experience and IT operations, all at 20% lower cost at [indiscernible]. We believe this new system will allow us to quickly become a top player in the $5 billion high growth hyper converged market. Also later this month, we will refresh our server portfolio to include a game changing new technology called Persistent Memory, which was invented by our server group. 
This new technology will enable an ecosystem of new applications supporting non-volatile memory and is a key milestone on our journey to the machine. So overall, I'm very pleased with our first quarter as an independent company. We are already seeing the benefits of being a smaller, more focused organization and I'm excited about what's ahead. 
On that note, I will hand the call over to Tim

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Meg. Good afternoon, everyone. We have now completed our first quarter as a stand-alone company and overall, I'm pleased with our performance. As part of the separation process, we delivered a clear financial architecture for HPE where each busine
componenttext:
Thanks, Meg. Good afternoon, everyone. We have now completed our first quarter as a stand-alone company and overall, I'm pleased with our performance. As part of the separation process, we delivered a clear financial architecture for HPE where each business segment has a specific role in driving overall company performance. 
Enterprise Group is our growth engine. Enterprise Services is committed to stabilizing revenue and expanding margins. Software provides high margins and strong cash flow. And financial services provides a consistent annuity-based revenue stream. 
After only 1 quarter, it's already clear that each business is executing against this framework and as a result, it driving solid financial performance at the HPE level. First quarter revenue was $12.7 billion, down 2.5% year-over-year, but up 3.8% in constant currency. And as Meg said, this marks our third consecutive quarter of year-over-year constant currency growth. Clearly, currency was a significant headwind this quarter. You might recall that we saw the most significant movement in currencies during our first fiscal quarter last year, which drove a large rate translation impact this year and a total currency impact of 6 points year-over-year. 
Going forward, currency will still be a significant impact in Q2 and then moderate in the second half and we still anticipate a currency headwind of approximately 3 points to revenue for the full year. Looking at performance by geography. We had some challenges in the Americas, which grew 1% year-over-year in constant currency with increased weakness in January, particularly in U.S. hardware as macro uncertainty cause a slowdown in global account spending. 
EMEA delivered growth of 4% year-over-year and constant currency, driven by balanced growth across EG hardware. APJ saw the best growth at 9% year-over-year in constant currency due to strengthened servers and record China networking revenue. The gross margin was 28.4%, down 1.2 points sequentially due to normal seasonality and up 70 basis points year-over-year primarily driven continued productivity improvements and Enterprise Services. Non-GAAP operating expenses of $2.6 billion were up 3%year-over-year, driven by R&D as we continue to make targeted investments. 
Non-GAAP operating profit was 8.1%, down 1.5 points sequentially and down 40 basis points year-over-year. Non-GAAP diluted net earnings per share was $0.41, at the top of our guided range. Non-GAAP EPS primarily excludes pretax charges of $311 million for restructuring charges, $218 million for amortization of intangible assets, and $79 million for separation costs. We delivered GAAP diluted net earnings per share of $0.15, $0.02 above our previously provided outlook range of $0.09 to $0.13 due primarily to tax indemnification adjustments related to the separation. 
Free cash flow was negative $831 million, down 70% year-on-year on an adjusted basis, that reflects the estimated HPE contribution to the combined HPE company free cash flow last year. As we discussed during the Q4 earnings call, Q1 is usually our lowest cash flow quarter due primarily to earnings seasonality in ES and software as well as normal annual bonus compensation payments. You can see the seasonal in our adjusted fiscal '15 results when our free cash flow for Q1 was a use of approximately $500 million. In addition, the normal seasonality in Q1 '16 we had higher separation payments year-over-year, which are now largely compete and higher usage of working capital. 
Let me explain what's happening with working capital. The cash conversion cycle was 31 days, up 8 days sequentially. This was above our targeted level of mid-20 days, primarily due to payables that were impacted by intra quarter purchasing linearity and strategic buys that provide an economic benefit to the company. These items are largely timing-related and we continue to more aggressively manage our working capital and expect the cash conversion cycle to improve throughout the year and returned to our targeted levels. With all that in mind, we remain committed to our free cash flow outlook of $2 billion to $2.2 billion for the full year. 
Turning to capital allocation. In the first quarter, we paid approximately $1.2 billion for share repurchases, including $1.1 billion through an accelerated share repurchase program and an additional $132 million on the open market as part of our ongoing share repurchase program. 
We also distributed $96 million as part of our normal dividend. To date, we have already returned over 60% of our free cash flow outlook to shareholders and now we are raising our commitment and expect to return at least 100% of our free cash flow outlook to shareholders in fiscal year '16. 
Separately as Meg noted, we expect the Tsinghua transactions to close near the end of May. When the deal closes, we expect to receive cash of just over $2 billion that is net of some initial on the sale. We are planning to use the vast majority of this cash to opportunistically repurchase shares. The timing of the repurchases may not be linear and will be dependent on several factors, including market conditions and availability of U.S. cash. 
Now turning to the business results. The Enterprise Group delivered healthy growth and stable profitability in line with our financial architecture. As Meg discussed, we are investing in innovation across EG to deliver best-in-class solutions in growing markets while maintaining cost discipline and solid profitability. Revenue grew 1% year-over-year as reported or 7% in constant currency with strength across all hardware groups. Profitability was down 1.8 points to 13.4%, primarily due to FX and to a lesser extent, product mix. 
Service revenue was down 1% year-over-year as reported but grew 5% in constant currency. Growth was driven by strong Tier 1 and by core sales in both EMEA and APJ. This was somewhat offset by pressure in the Americas towards the end of the quarter. Our R&D investments continue to pay off with our industry-leading offerings and high performance compute that now exceed the $1 billion run rate and strong double-digit growth in mission-critical x86 servers. 
Looking forward, we continue to see opportunities for profitable revenue growth and shared expansion in a server market. We have the most comprehensive and compelling server portfolio with solutions for every workload. And we are aggressively taking advantage of the uncertainty in the markets surrounding our competitors. Storage revenue declined 3% year-on-year as reported but grew 3% in constant currency. The unified 3PAR architecture combined with our excellent channel partnerships continues to drive revenue growth and share gains while our competitors are distracted and contracting. 3PAR all flash grew single-digits [ph] again driving 3PAR revenue growth of 21% year-over-year in constant currency. Significantly outperforming the market. 3PAR plus XP plus EVA was up 15% year-over-year in constant currency. 
We estimate that we've gained solid market share in the fourth [ph] calendar quarter and expect storage to continue to be a growth driver in constant currency throughout the remainder of the year. Networking revenue grew 54% year-over-year as reported or 62% in constant currency and expanded operating margins, driven by the acquisition of Aruba and strong execution across all regions. When adjusted for Aruba, networking revenue was still up double-digits in constant currency. 
The Aruba acquisition continues to prove to be a key strategic move for HPE and has transformed our networking business. Consistent with our acquisition strategy, Aruba continues to drive growing in wireless and has also been integral in return switching to double-digit growth year-over-year. ES revenue declined 9% year-over-year as reported or 3% in constant currency. However, approximately 1 point of the decline was due to the discontinuation of HPI related service contract that was supported by TS last year. Encouragingly, TS support which has significantly higher margins and consulting, continue to stabilize and revenue is only down 2% year-over-year in constant currency, including the HPI impact. 
Orders were down slightly in constant currency but up, excluding China where signings have been delayed ahead of the Tsinghua deal close date. Enterprise Services executed well against its plan to stabilize the top line and expand margins. Revenue declined 6% year-over-year but grew slightly in constant currency. Applications in business services, which you'll recall is the higher-margin business within ES, continue to improve with the second consecutive quarter of year-over-year revenue growth in constant currency, driven by strong apps performance and stabilization and business process services. Strategic Enterprise Services revenue was up double-digits year-on-year with strong growth in Helion-managed cloud. 
Overall, TCV was up nearly 30% year-over-year in constant currency, driven by strong renewals as well as growth in new logos and add-ons. ES operating profit improved 2.1 points year-over-year to 5.1% as the team continued to execute productivity improvements and delivering on sales and improved new deal productivity. We also had a benefit from a onetime divestiture of a noncore business. We continue to make progress against the cost take out plan we laid out at our Analyst Meeting. 
We now have approximately 45% of our workforce and low-cost locations and are well on our way to our longer term goal of 60%. Given the progress we have made on bookings and cost improvements along with our normal quarterly seasonality, we remain confident in our full-year operating profit outlook of 6% to 7% and revenue down 2% to flat year-over-year in constant currency. Software executed well in the quarter, improving revenue and delivering strong profitability while continuing to become more tightly integrated with the rest of the HPE portfolio and go-to-market approach. 
Revenue declined 10% year-over-year as reported or 6% in constant currency, but was up 1% when adjusted for acquisitions and divestitures in constant currency. We strong performance in Big Data and also some growth in security, offset by declines in IT management. SaaS had a very good quarter growing double-digits in constant currency when adjusted for divestitures, driven by ADMI and security. 
Operating profit was 17.4% down 60 basis points year-over-year due primarily to currency and higher mix of professional services. The team continue to focus on disciplined cost controls but is still making strategic R&D investments in growth areas that aligned well with the broader HPE portfolio. In financial services, revenue declined 3% year-over-year but grew 3% in constant currency as we began to see more impact from the volume growth we delivered last year. Financing volume in the quarter declined 4% year-over-year but was up 3% in constant currency. Operating profit improve that 1.7 points year-over-year to 12.9% as we were able to adjust that debt reserves to reflect the high-quality portfolio. 
Return on equity was up 1 point year-over-year to 18.1%. Now turning to our outlook. We will not formally update our fiscal year '16 outlook for the impact of Tsinghua transaction until after it closes, but I wanted to give you some information about how to think about the potential impact. We now anticipate the deal will close near the end of May and expect the transaction will impact fiscal year '16 EPS operationally by approximately $0.05. 
This includes some stranded costs from corporate administrative functions that we will mitigate in the near term. After the transactions closes, we will update our fiscal year '16 free cash flow and EPS outlook, including any expected benefit from share repurchases made with the sale proceeds. Also, we do have an EPS benefit from our share repurchases completed Q1 and still feel confident in the underlying operating performance of the business. But it's too early in the year to change our full-year outlook given the softness in January and near-term market uncertainty. 
With that in mind, we expect non-GAAP diluted net earnings per share to be $0.39 to $0.43 in Q2 2016, and continue to expect full year fiscal 2016 non-GAAP diluted net earnings per share of $1.85 to $1.95. We expect GAAP diluted net earnings per share to be $0.13 to $0.17 in Q2 2016, and continue to expect full year fiscal 2016 GAAP diluted net earnings per share of $0.75 to $0.85. 
Now let's open it up for questions.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question will come from Sherri Scribner of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question will come from Sherri Scribner of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good job on the operating margins. I was hoping you could give us some detail about how you're thinking about margins particularly in the Enterprise Group as we move through fiscal '16? And some of the other operating margins. I know you've commented on E
componenttext: Good job on the operating margins. I was hoping you could give us some detail about how you're thinking about margins particularly in the Enterprise Group as we move through fiscal '16? And some of the other operating margins. I know you've commented on Enterprise Services, but wanted to get your sense about the Enterprise Group in particular with the new products coming out.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Sherri. We did see some margin deterioration year-over-year if you look at the margins for EG in total, there are 13.4%. Most of that was driven by FX. So keep in mind in the first quarter last year, the euro was an example was kind of 1.24 and the
componenttext: Sure, Sherri. We did see some margin deterioration year-over-year if you look at the margins for EG in total, there are 13.4%. Most of that was driven by FX. So keep in mind in the first quarter last year, the euro was an example was kind of 1.24 and the average accounting rates in the first quarter of this year is 1.08 [ph]. So we still saw significant pressure from a FX perspective when you look at the first quarter. Going out for the rest of the year, we would expect the margin to stabilize and maybe get a little bit of a lift, particularly as we continue to grow the storage business as well as the networking business. So as you know, those businesses have a healthier margin profile. So as we continue to grow those, we should see some lift there. And then the other -- the only other major comment I'd make is on the ES business, again we saw great performance in the first quarter margins at 5.1%, up 210 basis points year-over-year. So the efforts of the team continues to execute upon as their transforming that business that we and the seasonality in that business we would expect those margins to improve over the course of the year and settle on average in the range of 6% to 7% as we talked about at the Analyst Meeting in September.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Perfect. And then just thinking about your free cash flow guidance, now you're planning to spend 100% of your free cash flow, returning that to shareholders. Does that change your acquisition strategy? What are you thinking about acquisitions this y
componenttext: Okay. Perfect. And then just thinking about your free cash flow guidance, now you're planning to spend 100% of your free cash flow, returning that to shareholders. Does that change your acquisition strategy? What are you thinking about acquisitions this year?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we continue to execute a return-based capital allocation strategy. And given where the stock price has been trading, this is one of the best return on investment that we can actually make. And as I said when we were on our roadshow for the new Hewlett-
componenttext: So we continue to execute a return-based capital allocation strategy. And given where the stock price has been trading, this is one of the best return on investment that we can actually make. And as I said when we were on our roadshow for the new Hewlett-Packard underprice, our first choice is from an integration perspective is organic innovation. Look at the success of the 3, 4 all flash storage array, internally homegrown, growing 3x the rate of the market and gives that benefit of the common architecture the benefit of growing in the you don't wake up with the Frankenstein of architectures. The second choice with the acquisitions that look like 3PAR, pre-com and Aruba. These have been very successful acquisitions for us. There additional complementary technology that goes to our excellent distribution system. But again, where the stock is trading right now, we think that this makes a lot of sense to buy back shares, which is why we've decided to go to 100% of the free cash flow.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks. Thanks, Sherri.
componenttext: Thanks. Thanks, Sherri.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question will come from Kulbinder Garcha of Credit Suisse.
componenttext: The next question will come from Kulbinder Garcha of Credit Suisse.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just have a couple of clarifications actually, maybe for Meg, first of all, when Tim touched upon this, you he talked about how you're seeing constant currency revenue for at the end of 2010. Are we now at the point where by -- this is sustainably I'm a
componenttext: I just have a couple of clarifications actually, maybe for Meg, first of all, when Tim touched upon this, you he talked about how you're seeing constant currency revenue for at the end of 2010. Are we now at the point where by -- this is sustainably I'm asking for a number of percentage growth rate. But if you have that availability because the reason I ask is Tim also mentioned visibility in January. And, obviously, you can see what the market is doing in the macro. Some kind of curious how we see sustainable growth in the business. And then also just with Tim on the enterprise service margin guidance at a growth margins for this year given the contract value growth, given the mix shift you're seeing in the business the cost of changes going through very well why is that guidance Enterprise Services now very conservative. Is there some caution you reflecting in that guidance obviously, on the young enterprise side specifically?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So on the overall growth rate of the company, remember we said at the beginning of this year that we would grow Hewlett-Packard in revenues, in revenues and constant currency. And we are on track to do that as you can see from Q1. Again, from a -- an
componenttext: Yes. So on the overall growth rate of the company, remember we said at the beginning of this year that we would grow Hewlett-Packard in revenues, in revenues and constant currency. And we are on track to do that as you can see from Q1. Again, from a -- an as-reported basis the compares get earlier, I mean get better in the second half of the year because we worked through those big currency fluctuations in Q1 of last year. And I think your question is can we see accelerated growth. I think we just are a little concerned about the macroeconomic environment. We saw a slowdown in the U.S. in the last 3 weeks of January. Linearity to be back on track, but it's early in the game. And so I think we're just being a bit cautious year. We've like our product portfolio, we like our go-to-market changes we like our innovation engine. There's a lot of things that we're feeling very good about that the macro environment still has pockets of weakness. Russia continues to be a big challenge to the Ukraine, parts of Latin America, China right now for us is doing really well but that can change in any minute. So we feel good about the stated goal of constant currencies and let's see how the macroeconomic and how sort of the political environment changes over time.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. And then on the ES point, again we feel great about the progress we've made in the first quarter. We have the delivery sensors in motion. We continue to move folks from high costs countries to low-cost countries. So the team has done a tremendous jo
componenttext: Sure. And then on the ES point, again we feel great about the progress we've made in the first quarter. We have the delivery sensors in motion. We continue to move folks from high costs countries to low-cost countries. So the team has done a tremendous job in transforming the business. Now to your question is to continue to progress in the year we're going to continue to see pricing pressure in that business is very competitive we're going to continue to invest in that business particularly in that go-to-market motion. So also given the fact that it's really just the first quarter so we have 9 more months to go there is some market uncertainty out there so we just thought it prudent to stick with the 6% to 7%.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Tony [indiscernible] Bernstein.
componenttext: The next question comes from Tony [indiscernible] Bernstein.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering if you can update us on the status of expected restructuring and separation charges. I think as of last call, you've talked about $1.7 billion in cash impact this year and that you expect it to be front and loaded. It ended up being less tha
componenttext: I'm wondering if you can update us on the status of expected restructuring and separation charges. I think as of last call, you've talked about $1.7 billion in cash impact this year and that you expect it to be front and loaded. It ended up being less than 1 quarter of the years total. And so I'm wondering if a, you can give us an update on how many people came out in the quarter, what expectation is for the year; and are we incorrect in what I just played back in terms of understanding that this didn't appear to be more front and loaded. In fact, it felt less than the near and why that might be.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Tony. A couple of things that I'd say about the restructuring. We are on track. So as of the called out in the Analyst Meeting, it will be about $1.2 billion in cash so we are on track for that this year. And then as far as Hominy folks we have take
componenttext: Sure, Tony. A couple of things that I'd say about the restructuring. We are on track. So as of the called out in the Analyst Meeting, it will be about $1.2 billion in cash so we are on track for that this year. And then as far as Hominy folks we have taken out so far it will be 3000 in the first quarter. We don't really guide and what we're going to take out for the entire year, but the only thing I'd say is we're on track and that 1.2 billion in cash for this year still remains there.

componenttextpreview: And separation? That was $600 million I believe, and you did $79 million in the quarter, where do you stand on that.
componenttext: And separation? That was $600 million I believe, and you did $79 million in the quarter, where do you stand on that.

componenttext: No, we did $300 million, you're right. It's $300 million in the first quarter.

componenttextpreview: And then finally, you mentioned the benefit from a divestiture in ES. Was that a margin benefit? And is that part of the reason for not being more optimistic about margins over the course of the year? Or was that either in material or revenue impact?
componenttext: And then finally, you mentioned the benefit from a divestiture in ES. Was that a margin benefit? And is that part of the reason for not being more optimistic about margins over the course of the year? Or was that either in material or revenue impact?

componenttext: No. That did have an impact from a margin perspective. I'd say it was not really material. It does have some impact on the margin to your point but overall we feel very good about the health of the ES margins.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just quickly to questions. One, bad debt reserves you mentioned was a benefit to financial services margins in the quarter. Was that a onetime benefit? Or does that flow through to future quarters? And then secondly, the sales to Tsinghua is taking longer
componenttext: Just quickly to questions. One, bad debt reserves you mentioned was a benefit to financial services margins in the quarter. Was that a onetime benefit? Or does that flow through to future quarters? And then secondly, the sales to Tsinghua is taking longer than expected. Can you just talk about what milestones are last ticket that deals completed and just some context around why that's been delayed.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, I'll hit the bad debt reserve and I'll let Meg talk about Tsinghua. So the bad debt reserve was a onetime benefit. It was about I think it was about 150 basis points of the improvement and it's primarily driven by the fact that we adjusted reserves.
componenttext: Sure, I'll hit the bad debt reserve and I'll let Meg talk about Tsinghua. So the bad debt reserve was a onetime benefit. It was about I think it was about 150 basis points of the improvement and it's primarily driven by the fact that we adjusted reserves. We're still very conservative but if you look at our loss reserves as a percentage of expected or historical losses, it's still at about 2x, which is very conservative in the financial services business.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Katy. Let me talk a little bit about Tsinghua. So you recall, we recently thought it would close at roughly the end of February and now we are confident that the deal is going to close near the end of May. And we're working through some final Chinese
componenttext: Yes, Katy. Let me talk a little bit about Tsinghua. So you recall, we recently thought it would close at roughly the end of February and now we are confident that the deal is going to close near the end of May. And we're working through some final Chinese regulatory approval, so all the U.S. approvals have been received et cetera only the China regulatory remains the call that the CSRC, which is a bit like our SEC. And there's been a couple of things going on there. One is they have a new head of the CSR C. Two, there is a big backlog of appeals and they're working through those that backlog. But we feel confident -- we expect that deal to close by the end of May. As you can imagine, we've been in contact with all the appropriate regulatory people. And, obviously, our partners at Tsinghua. So that's the way we think about it right now. There's also, as you know, a fair amount of volatility in the markets in China and I think that frankly, is slowing things down a little bit in China. And btw, the H3C revenue over there is doing great. We had a record revenue for our China networking business. And I take that as a positive sign. It means that the Chinese government is still leaning into HVC and that product and that business it has been well received in the China market.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Katy.
componenttext: Thanks, Katy.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016

componenttext: And our next session will come from Tim Long of BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to if I could. First quickly, Meg you mentioned a few times the January weakness, is just macro any parts of your business or verticals that it hit more meaningfully? And then onto the networking business. I think you mentioned Aruba helping the swit
componenttext: Just to if I could. First quickly, Meg you mentioned a few times the January weakness, is just macro any parts of your business or verticals that it hit more meaningfully? And then onto the networking business. I think you mentioned Aruba helping the switching business get back to double-digit growth. You just talk a little bit about is that AC driven? Or what is that that's helping those 2 businesses do such a good job of cross-selling?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the January weakness, we saw the last 3 weeks in January slow significantly in the United States. Actually not that dissimilar from what I believe Cisco or referred to on their call. And I don't have a good explanation of that, except for 1 or 2 t
componenttext: Yes. So the January weakness, we saw the last 3 weeks in January slow significantly in the United States. Actually not that dissimilar from what I believe Cisco or referred to on their call. And I don't have a good explanation of that, except for 1 or 2 things. One is, remember the opening week in the market in 2016 was really tough, right? And I think companies are quite now extra sensitive to volatility in the market. There quite quick to be cautious and pulled back purchases. From a vertical perspective, obviously, the weakest perspective was oil and natural gas. We saw that across the board in a lot of our oil and gas natural customers are in the United States, so that was a challenge and will probably continue. What I will say is while I'm conscious about it, it looks like February has returned to the linearity that we would have expected. Oil and natural gas continues to be a bit weak but there's some visit some other parts so I'm not quite sure what happened to those last 3 weeks but that would be my guess. Turning to Aruba and why it has helped our networking switch business. It's because customers now believe we're complete the committed to the networking business I mean, we are all in all, networking and while we had HP networking before, I think people thought well, maybe they're not 100% committed maybe a bit below scale below the acquisition of Aruba. They did a great deal of confidence in our product road map and our commitment to the business. And so Aruba, I think has cast a really nice glow over the rest of our HP networking business.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tim.
componenttext: Thank you, Tim.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question it comes from Maynard Um of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question it comes from Maynard Um of Wells Fargo.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just wondering if you could help us a little more in terms of granularity around quarterly free cash flow and the charges. In particular do you think that in the next quarter that your free cash flow will end up being positive and then continue to g
componenttext: I was just wondering if you could help us a little more in terms of granularity around quarterly free cash flow and the charges. In particular do you think that in the next quarter that your free cash flow will end up being positive and then continue to grow off of that? And then secondly, just in Enterprise Services are there any metrics you can provide or plan to give us at some point that to give us comfort on revenue stabilization whether it's book-to-bill or some other metrics?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. On the quarterly free cash flow, we're not going to guide on a quarterly basis. But if you think about it obviously, first quarter for us is seasonally low, and that's primarily driven by earning seasonality, right, which is, driven by the profiles
componenttext: Sure. On the quarterly free cash flow, we're not going to guide on a quarterly basis. But if you think about it obviously, first quarter for us is seasonally low, and that's primarily driven by earning seasonality, right, which is, driven by the profiles and DS and the software as well as the timing of that bonus payment which happens in the first quarter of every year it's a onetime payment. So we saw that same seasonality last year. Now going forward, what I would say is in -- we're going to get improvements every quarter in primarily 4 areas: one, earnings improvement so obviously, we are back and loaded from an earnings perspective particularly in the second half. So as those earnings improve obviously, our free cash flow will improve; the bonus payment is behind us now so that is no longer a drag as you go forward. The cash conversion cycle, I mean we were disappointed that the 31 days but when you look at the fundamentals of our terms and mix we're confident that, that will get back to the mid-20 day range sold that will drive a significant amount of improvement. And then lastly, the separation. So it to Tony's question, we had $600 million of separation charges planned for the year. We paid out $300 million of that in the first quarter. So that becomes less of a drag. So as we progressed through every quarter similar to last year, you will see improvement. So I think if you look at the seasonality of last year, that would probably give you a pretty good reflection of how it may play out this year.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let me talk a little bit about ES and your question on the revenue trajectory which you remember we said was negative 2% to flat at constant currency. So I think there's a couple of things going on here. One, is the first quarter of constant currency r
componenttext: So let me talk a little bit about ES and your question on the revenue trajectory which you remember we said was negative 2% to flat at constant currency. So I think there's a couple of things going on here. One, is the first quarter of constant currency revenue growth. Not a huge amount, 0.1% but relative to from where we come from the businesses given us a lot of confidence if the first quarter of constant currency revenue growth since Q3 of FY '12. And ABS, which is happens to have a higher level of profitability than ITO, posted second consecutive quarter of year-over-year constant currency growth FES as I've mentioned that's our cloud, Big Data, security practices rule over 30% year-over-year in Q1. And we saw some benefits from strong strategic enterprise signings in FY '15. I think we have also worked through the vast majority of the key account revenue runoff that we've talked about for the last couple of years. This were 3 or 4 very big ES customers that have now really run off and have become quite predictable. And then I got to give the finance team and operations team in ES credit. We are much better now at forecasting revenue than we have been. It's a very granular account by account forecast profit -- forecast of revenue by type of practice. And that gives us a lot of confidence. So as we sit here today and we look at the landscape and we see a book-to-bill ratio of roughly 1, we feel good about that negative 2% to flat.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Maynard.
componenttext: Thank you, Maynard.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Steve Marinovich of UPS.
componenttext: The next question comes from Steve Marinovich of UPS.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two things. First of all, if you could comment on the EMC Dell deal. I'm sure that you're going to say that its an opportunity to gain share, but do you have any proof points of that at this early date? And then second, you're going to be spending about $
componenttext: Two things. First of all, if you could comment on the EMC Dell deal. I'm sure that you're going to say that its an opportunity to gain share, but do you have any proof points of that at this early date? And then second, you're going to be spending about $4 billion on stock repurchase here over time and this at a time where IBM has had its biggest year of M&A Del and EMC are getting together there's probably more consolidation. Cisco is making a Playford a data center and you're very hardware centric. So it seems like you should be making some acquisitions here. Are you comfortable with a strategic position that leaves you in?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So let me talk a little bit about Dell EMC. And so it is interesting to note how different HP and Dell we have taken very different strategies in this environment. There's no question and my view of this is predicated upon the speed that this market
componenttext: Yes. So let me talk a little bit about Dell EMC. And so it is interesting to note how different HP and Dell we have taken very different strategies in this environment. There's no question and my view of this is predicated upon the speed that this market is changing. And so we decided to get smaller while they got bigger we decided to lean into new technology while there doubling down on old technology and a cost take out play. They levered up while we delevered. And we're super focused on being fast and nimble for our customers. So both strategies we work I happen to like our hand better than the Dell EMC hand. So how are we taking advantage of the disruption in the marketplace? So we learned a lot about how to do this in the context of IBM sale of their server business to Lenovo. We have a very focused channel play where we actually, it's called Smart Choice, and we have a big opportunity to go take the Dell and EMC business much as we have taken a lot of the Lenovo business that would have gone to Lenovo. And so we're seeing good results in the marketplace. We're rolling out our full sail efforts you're going to start to see even more advertising and digital as you capitalize on another one to two years of uncertainty as this deal closes and we work through the integration. The other thing is as you think about it, we continue to invest in innovation. And you have to think about Dell EMC as many ways owned by private equity and you can do your own calculation on when you think that debt is going through that, that interest payments is going to be for perspective, the entire EMC R&D budget is $2.7 billion. So we feel good about our hand to different strategies but I like where we are. In regards to M&A. As I said, we -- our first priority is organic innovation and are starting to see that innovation engine really kick into gear. And we started this if you'll remember 4 years ago, as we cut costs over the last 4 years, almost every single quarter year-over-year we spent more money on innovation and it's paying off. That doesn't say we won't do acquisitions. But I would rate the rate, it's returns based in the focused on companies like 3PAR, like 3Com, like Aruba, but our complement very technology, that fit into our overall 4 transformation areas as we go forward. So I think we're -- we got the right strategy here. We're thoughtful about it. But if the right acquisition comes along and we feel like the price is appropriate, we'll go ahead and do it.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: For what it's worth, I think the stock is really cheap too.
componenttext: For what it's worth, I think the stock is really cheap too.

componenttext: And that would be targeted for this year as well in terms of buyback? Or is that market dependent?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's really market dependent. I mean, it's hard to tell, I don't mean to be evasive, but it really depends on market conditions. It depends on the availability of U.S. cash, there are multiple variables in the overall equations. But we are committed to
componenttext: That's really market dependent. I mean, it's hard to tell, I don't mean to be evasive, but it really depends on market conditions. It depends on the availability of U.S. cash, there are multiple variables in the overall equations. But we are committed to returning a vast majority of that through share repurchases.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then Meg, on the hyper converged products you've mentioned, is that an organic product? And how meaningful do you expect it to be for revenue this year?
componenttext: Okay. And then Meg, on the hyper converged products you've mentioned, is that an organic product? And how meaningful do you expect it to be for revenue this year?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So it is an organic product, developed in-house in record time. And we're quite excited about this. The hyper converged market is big. It's growing fast. It's also getting pretty crowded, you've seen a lot of announcements over the last couple of mon
componenttext: Yes. So it is an organic product, developed in-house in record time. And we're quite excited about this. The hyper converged market is big. It's growing fast. It's also getting pretty crowded, you've seen a lot of announcements over the last couple of months. But we, very much like this product from a side-by-side comparison and features and functionality to our competitors. We feel really good about it and I think it means that we can be a leader in this quite large and fast growing part of the market.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Simona.
componenttext: Thanks, Simona.

componenttext: The next question will come from Wamsi Mohan of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, in your working cap comments, you noted headwinds from intra quarter linearity and some opportunistic purchases. What regions -- was it primarily the U.S. that drove that linearity difference or were there other regions that drove that difference? An
componenttext: Tim, in your working cap comments, you noted headwinds from intra quarter linearity and some opportunistic purchases. What regions -- was it primarily the U.S. that drove that linearity difference or were there other regions that drove that difference? And what components are you procuring opportunistically? And I have a follow-up.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It was primarily the U.S. but we did see some pressures across the globe. And again, if you think about timing challenges and free cash flow and cash conversion cycle, it's both sales and purchasing linearity. So this time around, it was a purchasing
componenttext: Yes. It was primarily the U.S. but we did see some pressures across the globe. And again, if you think about timing challenges and free cash flow and cash conversion cycle, it's both sales and purchasing linearity. So this time around, it was a purchasing linearity and then we also made some strategic buys.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And Meg, just a follow-up on the last question on hyper converged where do you think those dollars and hyper converged take away from over the next several years? And do you view it as cannibalistic in any of your converged offerings?
componenttext: Okay. And Meg, just a follow-up on the last question on hyper converged where do you think those dollars and hyper converged take away from over the next several years? And do you view it as cannibalistic in any of your converged offerings?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: There certainly is some cannibalism there, probably the converged infrastructure play. But I would say that this is part of a migration to the next generation data center. What we're seeing from customers of all size if your company is older than 5 or 10
componenttext: There certainly is some cannibalism there, probably the converged infrastructure play. But I would say that this is part of a migration to the next generation data center. What we're seeing from customers of all size if your company is older than 5 or 10 years, you're trying to figure out how you're going to take your existing infrastructure to the next generation of IT. And so this is part of the sale of okay, you can get more out of your existing IT if you transform to a hybrid infrastructure. And this is one of the core hardware components and software-defined components that allows you to get the most out of this next generation of IT. So listen, our business is cannibalistic, right? I mean, new companies come in to replace all products. But we think we can get an increased share of that data center spend which we see actually growing. And overall, the margins on CS our accretive to servers and into the ET group in general.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Wamsi.
componenttext: Thank you, Wamsi.

componenttext: The next question comes from Jim Suva Citigroup.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question is regarding the services segment. Recently, both the federal government as well as the military has talked about some big contrast coming up for renewal as well as potentially breaking them up into smaller pieces. And we're just wondering. Is
componenttext: My question is regarding the services segment. Recently, both the federal government as well as the military has talked about some big contrast coming up for renewal as well as potentially breaking them up into smaller pieces. And we're just wondering. Is there any risk there for HP about any of these contracts coming up specifically kind of midyear, second half similar event it will enter another realm of some more contracts running off?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Actually we think it's an opportunity for us because some of the contracts, at least the ones I'm aware of, are actually owned by many of our competitors. And so many these competitors, I know 1 in particular that's going to break from 1 and 2, 3 and
componenttext: No. Actually we think it's an opportunity for us because some of the contracts, at least the ones I'm aware of, are actually owned by many of our competitors. And so many these competitors, I know 1 in particular that's going to break from 1 and 2, 3 and we have a really good opportunity to get 1 out of those 3, that's right out in our sweet spot. As heads in widely reported in the U.S. Marines contract comes up I can't remember of its '17 or '18 I think its the end of '17, beginning '18 we have to start rebidding that. What we do we know how to do that we've done it for 4 years. So actually I think we're on the right side for most of these federal contracts that are breaking up.

componenttextpreview: Thank you very much. I think we have time for one more question please.
componenttext: Thank you very much. I think we have time for one more question please.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll just stick with one question. So Meg, can you talk a bit about what you're seeing in the cloud? And I know you've signed a deal with Microsoft and you talked a lot about hybrid cloud, but maybe you can talk a little bit about what you're hearing from
componenttext: I'll just stick with one question. So Meg, can you talk a bit about what you're seeing in the cloud? And I know you've signed a deal with Microsoft and you talked a lot about hybrid cloud, but maybe you can talk a little bit about what you're hearing from customers in terms of their thoughts of moving Azure or AWS solution versus maybe using more of a hybrid one? And then also how you're thinking about server impact this year and going forward from cloud given last year was so strong and you still have benefit I think this year from Jen 9.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. So what we've heard from customers is there's almost universal acceptance of their environments will be hybrid. And there's almost universal acceptance that it has to start with an analysis of the apps. How many apps that the customer want to h
componenttext: Yes, sure. So what we've heard from customers is there's almost universal acceptance of their environments will be hybrid. And there's almost universal acceptance that it has to start with an analysis of the apps. How many apps that the customer want to have? Is there opportunities to reduce the number of apps and consolidate? And then what do you want that apt to be on? Some apps are going to say locked down on the customers data center, untouched by anyone's hands other than their own employees. But some apps will go to a private cloud on-prem, a virtual private cloud, a managed private cloud and then obviously, to the private cloud. And we're seeing workloads move. Because even going from a traditional data center to the private cloud can be a 20% to 30% savings to a customer for that workload, which is meaningful. So as you know, we are the leader in private cloud. It is the first step that many customers take. And then they think okay, what would I like? What of my apps I like to have in a virtual Private cloud in the managed cloud. I think there is on from the sender only apps to Private cloud, BBC, NBC and ultimately to the public cloud. So one of the other things we're doing here is developing our multi-cloud management layer or one payment flash or orchestration automation of your multi-cloud environment. How do you deploy workloads to these different clouds quickly and efficiently? So I think we've got the right strategy here. I think it was smart to get out of our spending on public cloud. I think that game has moved to as you are and AWS, and maybe someday Google. And we're really pleased with our Azure partnership, so that's working well. The other thing that I would say is recall, is that we had built our cloud operation on Helion OpenStack. And our version 2.0 of what we call HOS, Helion OpenStack 2.0 is a significant improvement from 1.1 where we had some install or challenges, so we're getting a lot of good feedback around HOS 2.0 as well as our carrier-grade OpenStack, which is of course, of interest to the telcos. We had a very good Mobile World Congress show. I was there for 3 days and our open NFC solutions, we had 60 PLCs across the globe and a couple of very big customer wins. So I feel like we're on the right strategy. The world is changing at a breakneck speed, but we feel good about our strategy and I feel good actually about having chosen OpenStack. Two or 3 years ago, I was getting a little concerned because I wasn't sure how fast OpenStack was going to mature, but it seems like it's finally hitting many of the curve in the adult supervision and the number of big companies have provided that's actually helping.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And server thoughts?
componenttext: Great. And server thoughts?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Server. Yes, so we actually see growth in high performance compute, growth in Tier 1, Tier 2, Tier 3, Tier 4 service provider and in some parts of the world for service growth, but we got to make sure that we have the best server road map and the best opp
componenttext: Server. Yes, so we actually see growth in high performance compute, growth in Tier 1, Tier 2, Tier 3, Tier 4 service provider and in some parts of the world for service growth, but we got to make sure that we have the best server road map and the best opportunity for customers to run existing applications or cloud native apps. Hence, HPE synergy, which allows the developer to basically compose the infrastructure they need for their app. So HPE synergy isn't exactly cloud by any stretch of the imagination here, but it is in fact, the next generation of infrastructure for the software-defined data center. I would also say that we are gaining share in that market. There's no question about it. We did a great job I think in grabbing share from Lenovo as I said earlier when their servers moved from IBM, and we're all over this Dell EMC opportunity. So in a flat to declining market which probably core servers are at least over the next 5 years, we have to gain share. But there are real pockets of growth in the market as well. And HPC by the way, outperforms compute, we're like the last man standing there and we're investing in HPC, and it's a core competency for the company.
