headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you clarify whether you still expect constant currency revenue growth for all of fiscal '16, adjusting for the H3C divestiture? And if so, how do you think the second half would compare to the first half?
componenttext: Could you clarify whether you still expect constant currency revenue growth for all of fiscal '16, adjusting for the H3C divestiture? And if so, how do you think the second half would compare to the first half?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Yes, we do still expect to see revenue growth for the total year-end constant currency. The one thing that I would say is that the growth rates will be a little bit more normalized,  if you will, in the second half. There would be less FX pressure a
componenttext: Sure. Yes, we do still expect to see revenue growth for the total year-end constant currency. The one thing that I would say is that the growth rates will be a little bit more normalized,  if you will, in the second half. There would be less FX pressure as an example. Because again, if you look at the second quarter, most of that FX pressure was driven by the hedge gains we received in the second quarter last year that didn't repeat this year. So that will tend to normalize. So we expect to grow, but it will be a little bit more muted, I'd say, versus the first half. Because again compares get a little bit tougher, too, as well in the second half.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Kulbinder Garcha at Credit Suisse.
componenttext: The next question is from Kulbinder Garcha at Credit Suisse.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question's for Meg. Meg, you mentioned early on that you are a devotee I think of focus. And we've seen HP going from $100 billion business to a $50 billion business and now a $33 billion business. My question would be then, why would the remaining ass
componenttext: My question's for Meg. Meg, you mentioned early on that you are a devotee I think of focus. And we've seen HP going from $100 billion business to a $50 billion business and now a $33 billion business. My question would be then, why would the remaining assets, do they really belong together? Has any thought being given around optimizing the remaining portfolio further? For example, I think most people would understand that you have a reasonably subscale software businesses. Does that really belong with HP Enterprise? Have we thought about pruning even further going forward? Or do you think this is really the asset base and technology base HP Enterprise requires to thrive long-term?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we are happy with the performance of the overall portfolio. You saw the growth in EG. Software grew in constant currency when you normalize for M&A. And when you think about a software-defined data center, I'm really quite happy with the performan
componenttext: Yes, so we are happy with the performance of the overall portfolio. You saw the growth in EG. Software grew in constant currency when you normalize for M&A. And when you think about a software-defined data center, I'm really quite happy with the performance of the asset. So obviously over time, we continue to ensure that we've got the right set of assets. Somewhere early on the call asked whether we would do M&A or some divestiture. , we're going to continue to optimize the set of assets we have, but we're really happy with the current portfolio.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Rod Hall with JPMorgan.
componenttext: The next question is from Rod Hall with JPMorgan.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess I have 2. One, I wanted to see if you guys would walk us through the -- you said $4.5 billion of equity value, I think for 50% in the new entity. Can you just walk us through your calculation on that, how you're getting there? the second question,
componenttext: I guess I have 2. One, I wanted to see if you guys would walk us through the -- you said $4.5 billion of equity value, I think for 50% in the new entity. Can you just walk us through your calculation on that, how you're getting there? the second question, I wanted to go back to the synergies question and ask whether you think there would be any revenue dis-synergy? Is there overlap in revenues that would create some dis-synergy there, that we should be netting against the $1.5 billion incremental?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I'll get Mike Lawrie to address the revenue dis-synergies. I mean, he mentioned we have a very small overlap of customers, only 15%. But you might talk about that.
componenttext: Yes, so I'll get Mike Lawrie to address the revenue dis-synergies. I mean, he mentioned we have a very small overlap of customers, only 15%. But you might talk about that.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we just don't see that much dis-synergy here -- When we went through the top 200 accounts, we had less than a 15% overlap. So it's really 2 different customer sets. So when you think about it, it makes a lot of sense because many of our losses were H
componenttext: Yes, we just don't see that much dis-synergy here -- When we went through the top 200 accounts, we had less than a 15% overlap. So it's really 2 different customer sets. So when you think about it, it makes a lot of sense because many of our losses were HPE's gains and device versa, although it was mostly losses in our side. So when you think about it, it really is truly a new market opportunity for us. And that's why we don't think there will be many revenue dis-synergies and why there's such an opportunity to expand the business that we're doing together.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then well, let me walk you through at a high level of the deal mechanics. And then I'll ask, who is our Chief Operating Officer who helped negotiate this deal, to give a bit more detail. So we started out with what is the value of the Enterprise Servi
componenttext: And then well, let me walk you through at a high level of the deal mechanics. And then I'll ask, who is our Chief Operating Officer who helped negotiate this deal, to give a bit more detail. So we started out with what is the value of the Enterprise Services asset. And as you saw from the release, the headline value there is $8.5 billion. Now we wanted to make sure that we did a 50-50 merger of equals, tax-free spin merge of Enterprise Services into this new entity. And so obviously, we made some  -- we negotiated some adjustments to that. So first of all, the new company, and I'm sort of calling if for shorthand CSC ES, will pay Hewlett Packard Enterprise, the future stand-alone Hewlett Packard Enterprise, $1.5 billion of cash after the deal closes and will [ph] assume $2.5 billion of liability, pension liability as well as an old EDS $300 million bond. And then ES or Hewlett Packard Enterprise will actually subsidize some of that pension liability with offshore cash. So Chris, do you want any more detail to that?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Meg. Meg hit most of the high points. We started with negotiating, like Meg said, the $8.5 billion. And at the time that we did, the value, the equity value of CSC was about $4.6 billion. And we then developed  a -- in order to get to the 50-50 merg
componenttext: Sure, Meg. Meg hit most of the high points. We started with negotiating, like Meg said, the $8.5 billion. And at the time that we did, the value, the equity value of CSC was about $4.6 billion. And we then developed  a -- in order to get to the 50-50 merger of equals, to make this a tax-free spin under on RMT structure, we then developed a set of upfront considerations that Meg went through, with a cash dividend and then some transfer of liabilities. So that was roughly $3.9 billion. So the 2 components, the $3.9 billion of upfront considerations plus the $4.6 billion of equity consideration in CSC stock essentially makes up the $8.5 billion in total valuation. Now the equity consideration that CSC will essentially issue stock at the time of the transaction, and that stock will essentially result in the company being 50-50. And the price or the total value at the time of the close will depend on where CSC is trading at that point in time.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Steve Milunovich with UBS.
componenttext: The next question is from Steve Milunovich with UBS.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to go back to this question about the pull-through. I would think that ES, while some of it is very independent, would have pulled through a fair amount of your EG business, particularly as we move more to cloud. And I'd like you to talk a bit mo
componenttext: I wanted to go back to this question about the pull-through. I would think that ES, while some of it is very independent, would have pulled through a fair amount of your EG business, particularly as we move more to cloud. And I'd like you to talk a bit more about the commitments you have. Are you the favored hardware supplier for the new company? And I guess part of the point of being a pure services company is that they're fairly agnostic. And so do you lose that over time? So it's not obvious to me that you absolutely maintain what you have and is just a question of if it get better. I'm a little worried obviously about whether it could get worse. And then conversely, what does getting rid of the services business, or half of it, do for you on the HPE side? What can you do now that you weren't able to do previously?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So actually, we are very -- this was a very important part of the deal. Because the last thing I wanted to do was combine CSC with ES, and then lose the infrastructure pull-through. That would not have been a value to Hewlett-Packard Enterprise. So
componenttext: Sure. So actually, we are very -- this was a very important part of the deal. Because the last thing I wanted to do was combine CSC with ES, and then lose the infrastructure pull-through. That would not have been a value to Hewlett-Packard Enterprise. So we've negotiated a deal that I think is very fair. It allows CSC to continue to work with people they worked with in the past. But we've also gotten a commitment from them for the next 3 years. Beyond that, I'm very confident that the work we will do in Hewlett Packard Enterprise will earn our way to that commitment. I mean, think about our server lineup, our storage lineup, our networking lineup, our wired, wireless land lineup, converged infrastructure and Helion cloud platform. we do have, if you will, a safety net for the next 3 years. But I also -- one of the benefits of a pure play services company is to be able to work with best of breed, and I know Mike wants to continue to do that. So I think we struck a good thing that protects us in the near term, but gives Mike the flexibility he needs to do solutions that are right for his customers. On the other side of it is we do business today with some of ES competitors. Think about Deloitte or Accenture, Capgemini or the Indian players. And we want to continue to grow that. And they're, just like for Mike, there's a benefit to being a pure play that will be benefit for us in terms of being primarily a software defined infrastructure company and software company. So we imagine growing the business with those players as well. And by the way, this happened with the HPE, HP Inc. split. When HP Inc. became a separate company, all of a sudden a lot of competitors who used to think they were competitors to some degree with our company, all of a sudden are very interested in the HP Inc. offering. So I think that could happen to us as well.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Amit Daryanani at RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question is from Amit Daryanani at RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, Meg, the biggest question you're getting right now is what drove the transaction at this point for you guys? really broadly as a look at HPE post this transaction and up to March 31, what do you think your revenue growth and EPS targets would loo
componenttext: I guess, Meg, the biggest question you're getting right now is what drove the transaction at this point for you guys? really broadly as a look at HPE post this transaction and up to March 31, what do you think your revenue growth and EPS targets would look like relative to IT spend over time?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so listen, I mean, part of the benefit of this transaction is focus on a smaller number of businesses, but I think plya into a sweet spot in IT spend. So the objective of stand-alone HPE will be all about helping customers optimize and modernize thei
componenttext: Yes, so listen, I mean, part of the benefit of this transaction is focus on a smaller number of businesses, but I think plya into a sweet spot in IT spend. So the objective of stand-alone HPE will be all about helping customers optimize and modernize their traditional IT spend, which by the way is 88% of the spend in the marketplace, and transition to a multicloud environment. And also deploy obviously this software assets. So we -- we're not giving revenue guidance and EPS guidance for the stand-alone company. I'm certain we will closer to March 31. But we expect to go at or above the market rate as we did this quarter. I think it's important to look at our results this quarter for Enterprise Group and Software. I think they are the best indication that we've got a winning company here. We outgrew the market. We outgrew every single competitor, gained share in every single one of -- against our infrastructure competitors. And I think what you have now is the Enterprise Group and Software on a roll. And the investments that we have made in R&D, the investments we've made in a fire in the belly sales force. I mean, we have done a complete transformation of our sales force around not only our channel, but also direct selling. And then if you think about how we've optimized marketing spend over the last couple of years, we're doing better in demand gen, digital, marketing that we've ever done. So I think you've got a little powerhouse and software-defined infrastructure and Software.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Ittai Kidron at Oppenheimer.
componenttext: The next question is from Ittai Kidron at Oppenheimer.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Ittai, question for Tim. Tim, I wanted to drill down a little bit into third quarter guidance, especially on the EPS, which is below the Street by about $0.04. How much of this is the H3C transaction? I think you talked about $0.05 loss there. But
componenttext: This is Ittai, question for Tim. Tim, I wanted to drill down a little bit into third quarter guidance, especially on the EPS, which is below the Street by about $0.04. How much of this is the H3C transaction? I think you talked about $0.05 loss there. But -- is there also the reason you're looking for a very fourth quarter weighted EPS upside? Can you walk us through some of the elements for that variability?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So you take our third quarter guide, we're at the midpoint about $0.44. The primary delta versus consensus right now is really driven by the H3C transaction. To your point, that's probably about, I'd say, $0.03 or $0.04. that implies a ramp in the f
componenttext: Sure. So you take our third quarter guide, we're at the midpoint about $0.44. The primary delta versus consensus right now is really driven by the H3C transaction. To your point, that's probably about, I'd say, $0.03 or $0.04. that implies a ramp in the fourth quarter. And that's really, think about it in 3 ways. One, it's seasonality. So when you look at our ES business and our Software business, those businesses tend to be back-end loaded. So that will drive a lot of the improvement. The second component is around the H3C transaction from a stranded cost perspective. So now that the deal is closed, there is some overhead costs that we need to take out of the system. That generally takes a little bit of time, not to dissimilar to that dis-synergies story we had around the separation. and third component is driven by the share repurchases. So there's more of an impact in Q4 versus Q3 on the share repurchase front. So those are really the key drivers to the ramp in the fourth quarter, but we've got clear plans. For sure, we need to go out and execute, but we feel good about the total year. And that's why we held our total year guide of 1 85 to 1 95.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great. as a follow-up on EG margins, for 2 quarters in a row now, they're down on a year-over-year basis, and I understand that FX is a part of that. But how do we think about the time line by which we go back towards the 15% range? Is that even po
componenttext: That's great. as a follow-up on EG margins, for 2 quarters in a row now, they're down on a year-over-year basis, and I understand that FX is a part of that. But how do we think about the time line by which we go back towards the 15% range? Is that even possible, and given that mix of solutions? And maybe you can kind of walk us through that? And when does TS start contributing for this, from a growth standpoint revenue, not just margin?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I would say from a margin perspective, for sure FX has had a factor, has been a factor particularly if you look at the first half of the year. that will tend to have less of an impact going forward. We do have a heavy mix of Tier 1 right now, given
componenttext: Sure. I would say from a margin perspective, for sure FX has had a factor, has been a factor particularly if you look at the first half of the year. that will tend to have less of an impact going forward. We do have a heavy mix of Tier 1 right now, given again we launched cloud line in the second half of last year. So right now, you look at our mix from a Tier 1 perspective, it's a little bit heavy. Again, that will tend to normalize. So I would expect the margins in EG to be stable. And I'm not going to give margin guidance here. But again, as we continue to grow Aruba, as we continue to grow storage, that's going to help the margin front. On the TS front, that business will also stabilize. So we had -- we were down in revenue 1% in constant currency when you adjust for the HPI transaction. But we do expect revenue growth in the latter part of the year. And the way to think about that is obviously, that's an annuity type business, given the contracts. So what we're going to start seeing in the second half is that those negative growth orders that we had in '14, that's replaced by positive growth that we saw in '15. That feeds our 2016 revenue. So we do expect TS revenue to be flat on the year-over-year basis for the total year, and that will also help from a margin perspective as well.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Jim Suva Citi.
componenttext: The next question is from Jim Suva Citi.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Regarding the divestiture of the H3C, aside from the mechanics selling 51% and what goes on with equity transactions and how it accounts [indiscernible], from a pure sales perspective, was there an impact in this quarter and an impact in the next quarter
componenttext: Regarding the divestiture of the H3C, aside from the mechanics selling 51% and what goes on with equity transactions and how it accounts [indiscernible], from a pure sales perspective, was there an impact in this quarter and an impact in the next quarter as far as transactions, whether they be accelerated or deferred? Or anything we should think about as far as closing of transactions around the H3C transaction?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't think so, if I'm understanding your question correctly. Remember now, H3C is 51% in China is 51% owned by Unisplendor, a subsidiary of Tsinghua. So the CEO is a great guy by the name of Toni Yu [ph] who is running the business. Or -- we have th
componenttext: I wouldn't think so, if I'm understanding your question correctly. Remember now, H3C is 51% in China is 51% owned by Unisplendor, a subsidiary of Tsinghua. So the CEO is a great guy by the name of Toni Yu [ph] who is running the business. Or -- we have the Chairman and the CFO. But it's really going to depend on the momentum in that H3C business in the China market. And what I tell you is the momentum is really good. We had a very good second quarter there, even though the transaction hadn't closed. And I was just in China 2 weeks ago. And I will tell you, Tsinghua is incredibly committed to this. The management team is fired up. They feel like they control their own destiny in China. And so I can't predict what the revenue will do there, but I'm feeling really good about our 49% ownership of a business that I think there's a lot of commitment on behalf of Tsinghua and the management team to make successful.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess a follow-up regarding the flow-through. The 3-year agreement with CSC, is that on the HP services that goes to CS? Or CSC also in the other existing businesses kind of have an agreement to push for HP for their products?
componenttext: I guess a follow-up regarding the flow-through. The 3-year agreement with CSC, is that on the HP services that goes to CS? Or CSC also in the other existing businesses kind of have an agreement to push for HP for their products?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's really around -- so we sell a certain amount -- Hewlett Packard -- Enterprise Group and software, mostly Enterprise Group sells a lot of their products to Enterprise Services in an intercompany transfer today. we want to make sure that, that business
componenttext: It's really around -- so we sell a certain amount -- Hewlett Packard -- Enterprise Group and software, mostly Enterprise Group sells a lot of their products to Enterprise Services in an intercompany transfer today. we want to make sure that, that business stays for the next 3 years and we have a chance to earn more business. So think about it. It's servers, storage networking conversion infrastructure, the Helion platform NTS as well as software. So that's is how the agreement is structured. Does that answer your question?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes it does.
componenttext: Yes it does.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: other thing I would add is they are playing in a $2.5 billion ITO market today that we do not participate. And so it may be even a growth opportunity for HP.
componenttext: other thing I would add is they are playing in a $2.5 billion ITO market today that we do not participate. And so it may be even a growth opportunity for HP.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Wamsi Mohan at Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: The next question is from Wamsi Mohan at Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Apart from the separation costs associated with this transaction, can you talk about any potential cost dis-synergies or stranded cost associated with this deal? And I will follow up.
componenttext: Apart from the separation costs associated with this transaction, can you talk about any potential cost dis-synergies or stranded cost associated with this deal? And I will follow up.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes sure. So the overall separation costs will be $900 million. Again, $300 million of that will be incurred in '16, and $600 million of that will be incurred, roughly $600 million will be incurred in '17. Again, there is no incremental onetime cash costs
componenttext: Yes sure. So the overall separation costs will be $900 million. Again, $300 million of that will be incurred in '16, and $600 million of that will be incurred, roughly $600 million will be incurred in '17. Again, there is no incremental onetime cash costs associated with this. We will reduce the 2015 restructuring plan by about $1 billion, and that will offset the costs for here. As far as the stranded costs number, we will work those costs of the system. I think the good news is what we've learned in the last separation how to do this and how to do it efficiently. So I would say on the stranded costs piece, if I look at project planning I would have you, we have that much more clearly defined. We know who owns it and we know how that's going to come out of the system and when that comes out of the system.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. also I think there's a real benefit to having done one separation. The first time you do it, you get the best advice you can and you learn how to do it. This time, we have the this thing down to a science. And so I think a number of the same people a
componenttext: Yes. also I think there's a real benefit to having done one separation. The first time you do it, you get the best advice you can and you learn how to do it. This time, we have the this thing down to a science. And so I think a number of the same people are going to work on the separation. And I'm confident we're going to be able to work off of the stranded costs, probably faster than we did in version 1.0.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. as my follow-up, Tim, normalized free cash flow, given the higher transactional nature of the business post ES, I'm a little surprised you have fairly tight range of 3.5 to 3.8, if I heard you right. How should we think about the volatility of that
componenttext: Great. as my follow-up, Tim, normalized free cash flow, given the higher transactional nature of the business post ES, I'm a little surprised you have fairly tight range of 3.5 to 3.8, if I heard you right. How should we think about the volatility of that number? And then just longer term, normalize CapEx spend for HPE in a post-ES world?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me just clarify the 3.5 to 3.8, that was '16 with ES in it. So if you're looking to pull ES out from a normalized perspective, that's not what I was talking about. I was talking about some of our current guide with current separation, current res
componenttext: Yes, let me just clarify the 3.5 to 3.8, that was '16 with ES in it. So if you're looking to pull ES out from a normalized perspective, that's not what I was talking about. I was talking about some of our current guide with current separation, current restructuring, what have you. In general if you strip out ES, I think about obviously ES has more CapEx than the other businesses. From a normalized CapEx perspective, I think you could see our CapEx go down by about $500 million or $600 million. That's what we typically use for ES. So that's sort of how I think about it from normalized perspective. Again, we'll give some more color when we do SAM in October, but I think CapEx is a big driver.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: As I said, I think what we are doing by the announcements we made today is unlocking the value of these 2 companies. And remember, EG plus Software plus our Financial Services business is a faster growing, higher margin, more robust free cash flow busines
componenttext: As I said, I think what we are doing by the announcements we made today is unlocking the value of these 2 companies. And remember, EG plus Software plus our Financial Services business is a faster growing, higher margin, more robust free cash flow business. And I think now that with super focused mission, we're going to see some real benefits there. And then obviously by consolidating CSC with ES, I think we're going to get we'll cost synergies there.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question is  from Simona at Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Next question is  from Simona at Goldman Sachs.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just the last question then on the fundamentals that you're seeing out there. It sounded like you attribute strong performance in EG mostly to share gains, but can you also comment on the demand environment? And then just relative to those share gai
componenttext: Maybe just the last question then on the fundamentals that you're seeing out there. It sounded like you attribute strong performance in EG mostly to share gains, but can you also comment on the demand environment? And then just relative to those share gains, you touched a little bit on what drove that such as retooling the sales force, et cetera. Can you just comment a little bit more detail on any other factors driving your success there, whether it's related to solution selling or pricing or products or anything of that nature?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So listen, it is in uneven macro economic environment. I think Tim said that at first. And so different countries sort of go up and down in different regions. But overall, I think we feel very comfortable with our position in the traditional IT mark
componenttext: Sure. So listen, it is in uneven macro economic environment. I think Tim said that at first. And so different countries sort of go up and down in different regions. But overall, I think we feel very comfortable with our position in the traditional IT market and then in our ability to provide solutions in a multicloud environment. So I think demand can go up and down, but our objective is in whatever the market's doing, we want to make sure we at least hold or gain share, and we did that in the last quarter. And I don't think there's anything new to add as to why. First of all, I think the R&D investments we've made over the last 4 years are paying off. So the development cycle in servers, storage networking, those kinds of things, hyperconverged, these are long-term investments. What you started 3 years ago actually comes to the market now or even next year. So that investment in R&D is paying off. And I will tell you, $1 spent on internal R&D is best dollar we spent at HP. It's fantastic. Second is when you retool a sales force, that take some time as well. And I would say we're much farther along than we have been. There is more work to do. And then as I said marketing, we've retooled our entire demand generation. We've retooled -- and by the way, the launch of Hewlett Packard Enterprise gave us a chance to tell still people the story of the enterprise side of this business. Because prior to that, if you asked men on the street what is HPE, they's say printing and PC company. So I think that's actually been beneficial. And then turnarounds take 5 years. I said it when I started. And we're rounding the bend into the end of the fifth year. And so it's gratifying that we saw as reported growth for the first time in 5 years.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, thank you Simona. I think that wraps up today's call.
componenttext: Great, thank you Simona. I think that wraps up today's call.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much.
componenttext: Thank you very much.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you.
