headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Meg, can you just talk about the remaining portions of your business? It seems it's definitely more transactional. Do you anticipate that we should think about more transactions happening here, whether it's accelerated M&A or spinoffs or sale? How should
componenttext: Meg, can you just talk about the remaining portions of your business? It seems it's definitely more transactional. Do you anticipate that we should think about more transactions happening here, whether it's accelerated M&A or spinoffs or sale? How should we think about that? And then I have a follow-up.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks, Maynard. So we're actually very excited about what will become a stand-alone Hewlett Packard Enterprise. Our focus is going to be on next-gen software-defined infrastructure with a world-class portfolio of servers; storage; networking; conve
componenttext: Well, thanks, Maynard. So we're actually very excited about what will become a stand-alone Hewlett Packard Enterprise. Our focus is going to be on next-gen software-defined infrastructure with a world-class portfolio of servers; storage; networking; converged infrastructure; hyperconverged; Helion, our Helion cloud platform; and our software assets. And you probably have guessed by now that I am now a devotee of focus. And this is going to be a laser-like focused company that, as I think you know, is higher growth, higher margin with more robust free cash flows. And it's going to be well capitalized. So we don't necessarily think there is a need for acquisitions, but if we find the right companies, we certainly will move. And let me just recap the kind of acquisitions that have worked well for this company in the past: complementary technologies that we can put through our excellent distribution and support system. So think 3PAR, 3Com, Aruba. All 3 of those acquisitions have been fantastic for Hewlett Packard Enterprise. And so we'll keep our eyes out for those kinds of acquisitions. Unfortunately, there aren't a lot of those around. But to the extent we see them, we won't hesitate to move. And as Tim said, remember, our capital allocation strategy is returns based. Right now, we really think there's incredible value in our stock price. And Tim announced we're going to be buying back using 100% of our free cash flow in addition to half of the H3C proceeds. And we just got an increase in authorization of share buyback from our board.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just on the margin outlook for ES and Servers, how should we be thinking -- should we be thinking more along the lines of 7% to 9% margins now for the ES business and low teens digits on the Server side -- I'm sorry, the EG Group?
componenttext: Great. And then just on the margin outlook for ES and Servers, how should we be thinking -- should we be thinking more along the lines of 7% to 9% margins now for the ES business and low teens digits on the Server side -- I'm sorry, the EG Group?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. I would say on ES, as we talked about, we feel much more comfortable at the 7% range for this year. Again, we have a lot of momentum in that business. A lot of the activities that the team has done through the transformation are starting to see
componenttext: Yes, sure. I would say on ES, as we talked about, we feel much more comfortable at the 7% range for this year. Again, we have a lot of momentum in that business. A lot of the activities that the team has done through the transformation are starting to see through to the P&L. So 7% to 9% is what we would have. It may be conservative, but again, we need to get some -- continue to execute, and there's more work to do there. So we're prudent at the 7% to 9%. On the EG front, margins were down about 240 basis points. That's primarily driven by foreign exchange, some Tier 1 mix and, to a lesser degree, the R&D investments we've made. We are a little bit heavy in Tier 1 right now. If you recall, we launched the Cloudline product line, where we're seeing a lot of momentum. We launched that in the second half of last year, so we are a little bit heavier weighted in Tier 1. We expect that to normalize in the second half. I think margins there will be stable in the near term. And if you look longer term, we may even see some expansion or we'd expect to see some expansion as you think about further growth in Aruba, Converged Storage and those types of areas.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, Maynard, don't forget about when we get to -- in March 31, 2017, the combined company of CSC and our Enterprise Services division. We announced $1.5 billion of synergies on an ongoing basis, and we are really confident of that. And Mike, I might
componenttext: And then, Maynard, don't forget about when we get to -- in March 31, 2017, the combined company of CSC and our Enterprise Services division. We announced $1.5 billion of synergies on an ongoing basis, and we are really confident of that. And Mike, I might just ask you to comment on what you think in terms of the synergies of the new company.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've taken a pretty deep look at this and have categorized this. So we feel that we really have got a very actionable plan that we can begin to execute once we close the transaction at the end of March. So Meg, I think that number is a very strong n
componenttext: Yes, we've taken a pretty deep look at this and have categorized this. So we feel that we really have got a very actionable plan that we can begin to execute once we close the transaction at the end of March. So Meg, I think that number is a very strong number.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Toni Sacconaghi at Bernstein.
componenttext: The next question is from Toni Sacconaghi at Bernstein.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have a couple questions related to services and the transaction. I guess the first question is why now, Meg? The business has a lot of momentum in terms of profit improvement. I understand the $8.5 billion consideration, but this business is going to ea
componenttext: I have a couple questions related to services and the transaction. I guess the first question is why now, Meg? The business has a lot of momentum in terms of profit improvement. I understand the $8.5 billion consideration, but this business is going to earn over $1 billion in net income this year, could be closer to $1.3 billion, $1.4 billion going forward. So you're ascribing a value of 6.5x to 8x to that business when operating profit under your previous plan would have been growing pretty healthily. So I guess the question is why now when you were kind of at the cusp of improvement and, arguably, could have gotten paid for that in your stock price? And how did you determine the value? And I have a follow-up, please.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. So we are actually very pleased with the turnaround that we have executed in Enterprise Services. And I would say the time is right now because we believe this industry actually will consolidate, and it's better to be on the front end of a cons
componenttext: Yes, sure. So we are actually very pleased with the turnaround that we have executed in Enterprise Services. And I would say the time is right now because we believe this industry actually will consolidate, and it's better to be on the front end of a consolidation play than the back end of a consolidation play. And while there is more margin expansion here, we actually think the ability to accelerate the turnaround of ES will happen in the combined entity of CSC and ES. And recall that our shareholders will own 50% of this new entity, so they'll be party to that 50% of the synergies, 50% of the operational improvements, 50% of the synergy improvements. So in some ways, the shareholders get the best of both worlds. They get to maintain a position in Hewlett Packard Enterprise and a more focused software-defined data center and Edge strategy, and they get to ride the upside -- half the upside that they would have gotten had it stayed with us. And my view is the upside will be bigger with CSC and ES together. And I guess the other reason of why now is the business is in a good position. Two years ago, we were struggling in this business. We've diversified the revenue. We've taken cost out. Revenue has stabilized. We've developed some new product lines. And I think combined with CSC, it's going to be a powerhouse IT services company.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just a follow-up along those lines, Meg, so I'm trying to understand what will really be incremental from the merger. So you had outlined a 30,000-person headcount reduction as part of your original ES plan and gross savings of $2.7 billion. And so I'
componenttext: And just a follow-up along those lines, Meg, so I'm trying to understand what will really be incremental from the merger. So you had outlined a 30,000-person headcount reduction as part of your original ES plan and gross savings of $2.7 billion. And so I'd like to understand, when the deal is consummated, how much of that will have been captured? And then is the $1.5 billion you're talking about just the continuation of what was already in the plan? Or is it truly incremental? Because, at least by my math, a lot of it doesn't feel like it's incremental because I don't think you're going to be done with your original restructuring plan by March 31, 2017.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we will not be done with the entire restructuring plan, but we'll be done with a big chunk of it, basically, probably, I would say, 60% of it, maybe almost 70% of it. And that $1.5 billion of synergy is incremental. And it's things like, between the 2
componenttext: No, we will not be done with the entire restructuring plan, but we'll be done with a big chunk of it, basically, probably, I would say, 60% of it, maybe almost 70% of it. And that $1.5 billion of synergy is incremental. And it's things like, between the 2 companies, 95 data centers. Okay, we definitely do not need 95 data centers; multiple offshore locations and delivery centers, we will be able to consolidate delivery centers and leverage our position in India and China and Costa Rica and other places. We will be able to leverage our selling teams that will be able to, I think, do more in the context of this combined entity. So our estimate is those $1.5 billion of synergies is completely incremental, and we'll probably be 60% to 70% of the way through the transformation and the cost reduction.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Sherri Scribner at Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: The next question is from Sherri Scribner at Deutsche Bank.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping to get a little more detail on the impact of the H3C divestiture on the second half results. Primarily, is it going to show up in terms of lower revenue in the networking number? Or should we also see an impact to servers and storage from tha
componenttext: I was hoping to get a little more detail on the impact of the H3C divestiture on the second half results. Primarily, is it going to show up in terms of lower revenue in the networking number? Or should we also see an impact to servers and storage from that divestiture?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. You'll see that in the second half. It's about $0.05. We're estimating most of that is from operating profit. There is some stranded cost that we need to take out now that the deal is closed. You'll see most of that show up in the networking an
componenttext: Yes, sure. You'll see that in the second half. It's about $0.05. We're estimating most of that is from operating profit. There is some stranded cost that we need to take out now that the deal is closed. You'll see most of that show up in the networking and a little bit in TS as well.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. But on the revenue side, it'll mostly be on the networking?
componenttext: Okay. But on the revenue side, it'll mostly be on the networking?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Won't be much impact at all to servers or storage or converged infrastructure or the Helion cloud platform or our software or, frankly, ES, so...
componenttext: Won't be much impact at all to servers or storage or converged infrastructure or the Helion cloud platform or our software or, frankly, ES, so...

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, perfect. And then thinking about the divestiture of the Services business, how will you structure your private cloud solutions going forward? Will they sit on the HPE side? Will they sit on the new business side? And how will you offer those solutio
componenttext: Okay, perfect. And then thinking about the divestiture of the Services business, how will you structure your private cloud solutions going forward? Will they sit on the HPE side? Will they sit on the new business side? And how will you offer those solutions to your customers?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the Helion cloud platform as a whole will sit on the Hewlett Packard Enterprise side. So for example, private cloud, we're the world's leader in private cloud in our Helion cloud system platform that is built on OpenStack. And then, of course, sof
componenttext: Yes. So the Helion cloud platform as a whole will sit on the Hewlett Packard Enterprise side. So for example, private cloud, we're the world's leader in private cloud in our Helion cloud system platform that is built on OpenStack. And then, of course, software business around CSA and other products in terms of one pane of glass to manage a multicloud environment will sit with Hewlett Packard Enterprise. However, virtual private cloud and managed private cloud is today delivered by ES and, in the future, will be delivered by CSC-ES. And we'll just -- going to be working very closely together to make sure that there's a seamless offering in the marketplace when someone wants a private cloud plus VPC or MPC. And then, obviously, we have a relationship with Azure, and CSC has a relationship with AWS. So the new company will be able to offer both to customers, which I think is going to be a real benefit. And Mike, do you want to add anything to that?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's the real benefit is we're going to be able to provide for our clients a wide range of solutions. I'm anxious to be able to get access to some of the investments that, Meg, you and the company have made over the last couple years becaus
componenttext: Yes, I think that's the real benefit is we're going to be able to provide for our clients a wide range of solutions. I'm anxious to be able to get access to some of the investments that, Meg, you and the company have made over the last couple years because you've got some leading solutions and that all can be brought now to our customers through the sales force and the delivery forces that we have as a result of the combined companies.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Katy Huberty at Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: The next question is from Katy Huberty at Morgan Stanley.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, can you just clarify the free cash flow guidance for this year? Should we subtract the $300 million from the $2 billion to $2.2 billion range? Or do you expect to offset some of that $300 million hit? And then what is the normalized free cash flow wi
componenttext: Tim, can you just clarify the free cash flow guidance for this year? Should we subtract the $300 million from the $2 billion to $2.2 billion range? Or do you expect to offset some of that $300 million hit? And then what is the normalized free cash flow with all the divestitures in comparison to that $3.7 billion number that you talked about at the Analyst Day? Then I have a follow-up.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. So we are reducing the guide from $2 billion to $2.2 billion down to $1.7 billion to $1.9 billion, so that is the new guide for the year. And if you think about that, it's really 3 components. There's $200 million of pressure from the H3C dives
componenttext: Yes, sure. So we are reducing the guide from $2 billion to $2.2 billion down to $1.7 billion to $1.9 billion, so that is the new guide for the year. And if you think about that, it's really 3 components. There's $200 million of pressure from the H3C divestiture. So that does not show up in our free cash flow. There's about $300 million that are related to the separation costs now for the ES transaction. And then those will be partially offset by working capital improvement. So we continue to see momentum, particularly if you look at extended payment terms, if you look at just being a little bit more disciplined around payment exceptions and things of that nature. So net-net, we will reduce the guide by $300 million. I think about it as primarily driven by the H3C divestiture. From a normalized perspective, I would say normalized would probably be around maybe $3.5 billion, north of $3.5 billion, $3.5 billion, $3.8 billion, something like that.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, Meg, one of the reasons HP originally purchased EDS was the potential revenue synergies as that business pulled more HP systems and software. As you look to separate those businesses, are there revenue dis-synergies that we should now thin
componenttext: Okay. And then, Meg, one of the reasons HP originally purchased EDS was the potential revenue synergies as that business pulled more HP systems and software. As you look to separate those businesses, are there revenue dis-synergies that we should now think about?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, we don't believe that, that will be the case. You're right. One of the predicates of the EDS acquisition was pull-through of our Infrastructure business as well as our Software business. And by the way, that has been realized. So we've got a comm
componenttext: Yes. No, we don't believe that, that will be the case. You're right. One of the predicates of the EDS acquisition was pull-through of our Infrastructure business as well as our Software business. And by the way, that has been realized. So we've got a commercial agreement with the new company, CSC-ES, that will keep the level of pull-through the same for 3 years. Now we hope we will actually be able to do more with CSC because we haven't really had access to their book of business. And they've got a very strong business. And as Mike said, they're interested in our products and software, and we have to go in and earn that business. But that's one of the things that we intend to do. So at a very minimum, baseline will be maintained and there is an upside in terms of earning more business with CSC.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Brian Alexander of Raymond James.
componenttext: The next question is from Brian Alexander of Raymond James.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you just clarify whether you're still expecting constant-currency revenue growth for all of fiscal '16, adjusting for the H3C divestiture? And if so, how do you think the second half will compare to the first half?
componenttext: Could you just clarify whether you're still expecting constant-currency revenue growth for all of fiscal '16, adjusting for the H3C divestiture? And if so, how do you think the second half will compare to the first half?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Yes, we do still expect to see revenue growth for the total year in constant currency. The one thing that I would say is that the growth rates will be a little bit more normalized, if you will, in the second half, there will be less FX pressure as a
componenttext: Sure. Yes, we do still expect to see revenue growth for the total year in constant currency. The one thing that I would say is that the growth rates will be a little bit more normalized, if you will, in the second half, there will be less FX pressure as an example because, again, if you look at the second quarter, most of that FX pressure was driven by the hedge gains that we received in the second quarter of last year that didn't repeat this year, so that'll tend to normalize. So we expect to grow, but it will be a little bit more muted, I'd say, versus the first half because, again, the compares get a little bit tougher, too, as well in the second half.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Kulbinder Garcha at Credit Suisse.
componenttext: The next question is from Kulbinder Garcha at Credit Suisse.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question's for Meg. Meg, you mentioned earlier on that you are a devotee, I think, of focus. And we've seen HP go from being $100 billion business to a $50 billion business to now a $33 billion business. My question would be then, why would the remaini
componenttext: My question's for Meg. Meg, you mentioned earlier on that you are a devotee, I think, of focus. And we've seen HP go from being $100 billion business to a $50 billion business to now a $33 billion business. My question would be then, why would the remaining assets -- do they really belong together? Has any thought being given around optimizing the remaining portfolio further? For example, I think most people wouldn't understand that you have a reasonably subscale Software business. Does that really belong with HP Enterprise? Have you thought about pruning even further going forward? Or do you think this is really the asset base and technology base of HP Enterprise required to thrive long-term?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we're happy with the performance of the overall portfolio. You saw the growth in EG. Software grew in constant currency when you normalize for M&A. And when you think about the software-defined data center, I'm really quite happy with the performa
componenttext: Yes, so we're happy with the performance of the overall portfolio. You saw the growth in EG. Software grew in constant currency when you normalize for M&A. And when you think about the software-defined data center, I'm really quite happy with the performance of the asset. So obviously, over time, we continue to ensure that we've got the right set of assets. Someone earlier on the call asked whether we would do M&A or some divestiture, so we're going to continue to optimize the set of assets that we have, but we're really happy with the current portfolio.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Rod Hall with JPMorgan.
componenttext: The next question is from Rod Hall with JPMorgan.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess I have 2. One, I wanted to see if you guys could walk us through the -- you said $4.5 billion of equity value, I think, for 50% in the new entity. Can you just walk us through your calculation on that? How you're getting there, and then the second
componenttext: I guess I have 2. One, I wanted to see if you guys could walk us through the -- you said $4.5 billion of equity value, I think, for 50% in the new entity. Can you just walk us through your calculation on that? How you're getting there, and then the second question, I wanted to go back to the synergies question and ask whether you think there'll be any revenue dis-synergy. Is there overlap in revenues that would create some dis-synergy there that we should be netting against the $1.5 billion incremental?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I'll get Mike Lawrie to address the revenue dis-synergies. I mean, he mentioned that we have a very small overlap of customers, only 15%. But you might talk about that.
componenttext: Yes. So I'll get Mike Lawrie to address the revenue dis-synergies. I mean, he mentioned that we have a very small overlap of customers, only 15%. But you might talk about that.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we just don't see that much dis-synergy here with the -- when we went through the top 200 accounts, we had less than a 15% overlap. So it's really 2 different customer sets. So when you think about it, it makes a lot of sense because many of our loss
componenttext: Yes, we just don't see that much dis-synergy here with the -- when we went through the top 200 accounts, we had less than a 15% overlap. So it's really 2 different customer sets. So when you think about it, it makes a lot of sense because many of our losses were HPE's gains and vice versa, although it was mostly losses on our side. So when you think about it, it really is truly a new market opportunity for us. And that's why we don't think there'll be many revenue dis-synergies and why there's such an opportunity to expand the business that we are doing together.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then let me walk you through, at a high level, the deal mechanics. And then I'll ask Chris Hsu, who is our Chief Operating Officer, who helped negotiate this deal, to give a bit more detail. So we'd started out with what is the value of the Enterprise
componenttext: And then let me walk you through, at a high level, the deal mechanics. And then I'll ask Chris Hsu, who is our Chief Operating Officer, who helped negotiate this deal, to give a bit more detail. So we'd started out with what is the value of the Enterprise Services asset. And as you saw from the release, the headline value is -- is there is $8.5 billion. Now we wanted to make sure that we did a 50-50 merger of equals, tax-free spin merge of Enterprise Services into this new entity. And so obviously, we made some -- we negotiated some adjustments to that. So first of all, the new company, and I'm sort of calling it, for shorthand, CSC-ES, will pay Hewlett Packard Enterprise -- the future stand-alone Hewlett Packard Enterprise $1.5 billion of cash after the deal closes and will assume $2.5 billion of liability, pension liability as well as a old EDS $300 million bond. And then ES or Hewlett Packard Enterprise will actually subsidize some of that pension liability with offshore cash. So Chris, do you want add any more detail to that?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Meg. Meg, you hit most of the high points. We started with negotiating, like Meg said, the $8.5 billion. And at the time that we did, the value -- the equity value of CSC was about $4.6 billion. And we then developed a -- in order to get to the 50-5
componenttext: Sure, Meg. Meg, you hit most of the high points. We started with negotiating, like Meg said, the $8.5 billion. And at the time that we did, the value -- the equity value of CSC was about $4.6 billion. And we then developed a -- in order to get to the 50-50 merger of equals to make this a tax-free spin under an RMT structure, we then developed a set of upfront considerations that Meg went through with the cash dividend and then some transfer of liabilities, so that was roughly $3.9 billion. So the 2 components, the $3.9 billion of upfront considerations plus the $4.6 billion of equity considerations in CSC stock, essentially makes up the $8.5 billion in total valuation. Now the equity considerations that CSC will essentially issue stock at the time of the transaction, and that stock will essentially result in the company being 50-50. And the price or the total value at the time of close will depend on where CSC is trading at that point in time.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Steve Milunovich at UBS.
componenttext: The next question is from Steve Milunovich at UBS.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to go back to this question about the pull-through. I would think that ES, while some of it is very independent, would have pulled through a fair amount of your EG business, particularly as we move more to cloud. And I'd like you to talk a bit mo
componenttext: I wanted to go back to this question about the pull-through. I would think that ES, while some of it is very independent, would have pulled through a fair amount of your EG business, particularly as we move more to cloud. And I'd like you to talk a bit more about the commitments that you have. Are you the favored hardware supplier for the new company? And I guess, part of the point of being a pure services company is that they're fairly agnostic. And so do you lose that over time? So it's not obvious to me that you absolutely maintain what you have and it's just a question of if it gets better. I'm a little worried, obviously, about whether it could get worse. And then, conversely, what does getting rid of the services business or half of it do for you on the HPE side? What can you do now that you weren't able to do previously?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So actually, we're very -- this was a very important part of the deal because the last thing I wanted to do was combine CSC with ES and then lose the infrastructure pull-through. That would not have been of value to Hewlett-Packard Enterprise. So we
componenttext: Sure. So actually, we're very -- this was a very important part of the deal because the last thing I wanted to do was combine CSC with ES and then lose the infrastructure pull-through. That would not have been of value to Hewlett-Packard Enterprise. So we've negotiated a deal that I think is very fair. It allows CSC to continue to work with people they've worked with in the past, but we've also got a commitment from them for the next 3 years. Beyond that, I'm very confident that the work we will do in Hewlett Packard Enterprise will earn our way to that commitment. I mean, think about our server lineup, our storage lineup, our networking lineup, our wired-wireless LAN lineup, our converged infrastructure, hyperconverged and Helion cloud platform. But we do have, if you will, a safety net for the next 3 years. But I also -- one of the benefits of a pure-play services company is to be able to work with best-of-breed, and I know Mike wants to continue to do that. So I think we've struck a good thing that protects us in the near term but gives Mike the flexibility he needs to do solutions that are right for his customers. On the other side of it is we do business today with some of ES' competitors, think about Deloitte or Accenture, Capgemini or the Indian players. And we want to continue to grow that. And there -- just like for Mike, there's a benefit to being a pure play that will be benefit for us in terms of being primarily a software-defined infrastructure company and software company, so we imagine growing the business with those players as well. And by the way, this interestingly happened with the HPE, HP Inc. split. When HP Inc. became a separate company, all of a sudden, a lot of competitors who used to think they were competitors to some degree with our company, all of a sudden were very interested in the HP Inc. offering, so we think that could happen to us as well.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Amit Daryanani at RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question is from Amit Daryanani at RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, Meg, the biggest question we keep getting right now is what drove the transaction at this point for you guys? And really, broadly, as you look at HPE post this transaction and after March 31, what do you think your revenue growth and EPS targets
componenttext: I guess, Meg, the biggest question we keep getting right now is what drove the transaction at this point for you guys? And really, broadly, as you look at HPE post this transaction and after March 31, what do you think your revenue growth and EPS targets would look like relative to IT spend over time?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So listen, I mean, part of the benefit of this transaction is focus on a smaller number of businesses that I think play into a sweet spot in IT spend. So the objective of stand-alone HPE will be all about helping customers optimize and modernize thei
componenttext: Yes. So listen, I mean, part of the benefit of this transaction is focus on a smaller number of businesses that I think play into a sweet spot in IT spend. So the objective of stand-alone HPE will be all about helping customers optimize and modernize their traditional IT spend which, by the way, is still 88% of the spend in the marketplace and transition to a multicloud environment, and also deploy, obviously, the software assets. So we -- we're not giving revenue guidance and EPS guidance for the stand-alone company. I'm certain we will closer to March 31. But we expect to go at or above the market rate as we did this quarter. I think it's important to look at our results this quarter for Enterprise Group and Software. I think they are the best indication that we've got a winning company here. We outgrew the market. We outgrew every single competitor, gained share in every single one of our -- against our infrastructure competitors. And I think what you have now is the Enterprise Group and Software on a roll and the investments that we have made in R&D, the investments we've made in a fire-in-the-belly sales force. I mean, we have done a complete transformation of our sales force around not only our channel but also direct selling. And then if you think about how we've optimized marketing spend over the last couple years, we're doing better in demand gen digital marketing than we've ever done, so I think you've got a little powerhouse in software-defined infrastructure and software.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Ittai Kidron at Oppenheimer.
componenttext: The next question is from Ittai Kidron at Oppenheimer.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Ittai. A question for Tim. Tim, I wanted to drill down a little bit into your third quarter guidance, especially on the EPS, which is below the Street by about $0.04. How much of this is the H3C transaction? I think you talked about a $0.05 loss t
componenttext: This is Ittai. A question for Tim. Tim, I wanted to drill down a little bit into your third quarter guidance, especially on the EPS, which is below the Street by about $0.04. How much of this is the H3C transaction? I think you talked about a $0.05 loss there. But -- and is that also the reason you're looking for a very fourth quarter weighted EPS upside? Can you walk us through some of the elements for that variability?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So if you take our third quarter guide where at the midpoint, it's about $0.44. The primary delta versus consensus right now is really driven by the H3C transaction, to your point. That's probably about, I'd say, $0.03 or $0.04. So that implies a ra
componenttext: Sure. So if you take our third quarter guide where at the midpoint, it's about $0.44. The primary delta versus consensus right now is really driven by the H3C transaction, to your point. That's probably about, I'd say, $0.03 or $0.04. So that implies a ramp in the fourth quarter. And that's really -- think about it in 3 ways. One, it's typical seasonality. So when you look at our ES business and our Software business, those businesses tend to be back end loaded so that will drive a lot of the improvement. The second component is around the H3C transaction from a stranded cost perspective. So now that the deal is closed, there's some overhead costs that we need to take out of the system. That generally takes a little bit of time, not too dissimilar to the dis-synergy story we had around the separation. And then the third component is driven by the share repurchases. So there's more of an impact in Q4 versus Q3 on the share repurchase front. So those are really the key drivers to the ramp in the fourth quarter. But we've got clear plans. For sure, we need to go out and execute, but we feel good about the total year. And that's why we held our total year guide of $1.85 to $1.95.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great. And as a follow-up, on EG margins, for 2 quarters in a row now, they're down on a year-over-year basis, and I understand that FX is a part of that. But how do we think about the time line by which we go back towards the 15% range? Is that ev
componenttext: That's great. And as a follow-up, on EG margins, for 2 quarters in a row now, they're down on a year-over-year basis, and I understand that FX is a part of that. But how do we think about the time line by which we go back towards the 15% range? Is that even possible given the mix of solutions and maybe you can kind of walk us through that? And when does TS start contributing for this from a growth standpoint revenue, not just margin?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I would say from a margin perspective, for sure, FX has had a factor -- has been a factor, particularly if you look at the first half of the year. And that will tend to have less of an impact going forward. We do have a heavy mix of Tier 1 right now
componenttext: Sure. I would say from a margin perspective, for sure, FX has had a factor -- has been a factor, particularly if you look at the first half of the year. And that will tend to have less of an impact going forward. We do have a heavy mix of Tier 1 right now. Again, we launched Cloudline in the second half of last year. So right now, when you look at our total mix from a Tier 1 perspective, it's a little bit heavy. Again, that will tend to normalize. So I would expect the margins in EG to be stable. And I'm not going to give margin guidance here but, again, as we continue to grow Aruba, as we continue to grow Storage, that's going to help the margin front. On the TS front, that business will also stabilize. So we had -- we were down in revenue 1% in constant currency when you adjust for the HPI transaction. But we do expect revenue growth in the latter part of the year. And the way to think about that is, obviously, that's an annuity type business given the contracts. So what we're going to start seeing in the second half is that those negative growth orders that we had in '14, that's replaced by positive growth that we saw in '15. That feeds our 2016 revenue. So we do expect TS revenue to be flat on a year-over-year basis for the total year, and that will also help from a margin perspective as well.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Jim Suva at Citi.
componenttext: The next question is from Jim Suva at Citi.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Congratulations on a lot of work and the big surprise. Regarding the divestiture of H3C, aside just from the pure mechanics of selling 51% and what goes on with the equity transactions and how it accounts to you financially, from a pure sales perspective,
componenttext: Congratulations on a lot of work and the big surprise. Regarding the divestiture of H3C, aside just from the pure mechanics of selling 51% and what goes on with the equity transactions and how it accounts to you financially, from a pure sales perspective, was there an impact in this quarter and an impact in the next quarter as far as transactions, whether they be accelerated or deferred or anything we should think about as far as closing of transactions around the H3C transaction?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't think so, if I'm understanding your question correctly. Remember now, H3C is 51% -- in China, is 51% owned by Unisplendour, a subsidiary of Tsinghua. So the CEO is a great guy by the name of Tony Yu who is running the business. Or -- we have th
componenttext: I wouldn't think so, if I'm understanding your question correctly. Remember now, H3C is 51% -- in China, is 51% owned by Unisplendour, a subsidiary of Tsinghua. So the CEO is a great guy by the name of Tony Yu who is running the business. Or -- we have the Chairman and the CFO. But it's really going to depend on the momentum in that H3C business in the China market. And what I tell you is the momentum is really good. We had a very good second quarter there, even though the transaction hadn't closed. And I was just in China 2 weeks ago. And I will tell you, Tsinghua is incredibly committed to this. The management team is fired up. They feel like they control their own destiny in China. And so I can't predict what the revenue will do there, but I'm feeling really good about our 49% ownership of a business that I think there's a lot of commitment on behalf of Tsinghua and the management team to make successful.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then I have a follow-up regarding the pull-through of the -- I think you mentioned that 3-year agreement with CSC. Is that just on the HP Services that goes to CSC or CSC also with their other existing businesses kind of having an agreement to refer
componenttext: Okay. Then I have a follow-up regarding the pull-through of the -- I think you mentioned that 3-year agreement with CSC. Is that just on the HP Services that goes to CSC or CSC also with their other existing businesses kind of having an agreement to refer HP for their products?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it's really around -- so we sell a certain amount -- Hewlett Packard -- the Enterprise Group and Software, mostly the Enterprise Group, sells a lot of their products to Enterprise Services in an intercompany transfer today. And we want to make sure th
componenttext: No, it's really around -- so we sell a certain amount -- Hewlett Packard -- the Enterprise Group and Software, mostly the Enterprise Group, sells a lot of their products to Enterprise Services in an intercompany transfer today. And we want to make sure that, that business stays for the next 3 years and we have a chance to earn more business. So think about it. It's servers, storage, networking, converged infrastructure, the Helion cloud platform and TS as well as Software. So that is how the agreement is structured. Does that answer your question?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it does.
componenttext: Yes, it does.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: The other thing I would add is they are playing in a $2.5 billion ITO market today that we do not participate, and so it may even be a growth opportunity for HPE.
componenttext: The other thing I would add is they are playing in a $2.5 billion ITO market today that we do not participate, and so it may even be a growth opportunity for HPE.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Wamsi Mohan at Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: The next question is from Wamsi Mohan at Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Apart from the separation costs associated with this ES transaction, can you talk about any potential cost dis-synergies or stranded costs associated with this deal? And I will follow up.
componenttext: Apart from the separation costs associated with this ES transaction, can you talk about any potential cost dis-synergies or stranded costs associated with this deal? And I will follow up.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. So the overall separation costs will be $900 million. Again, $300 million of that will be incurred in '16 and $600 million of that will be incurred -- roughly $600 million will be incurred in '17. Again, there is no incremental onetime cash cos
componenttext: Yes, sure. So the overall separation costs will be $900 million. Again, $300 million of that will be incurred in '16 and $600 million of that will be incurred -- roughly $600 million will be incurred in '17. Again, there is no incremental onetime cash costs associated with this. We will reduce the 2015 restructuring plan by about $1 billion, and that will offset the costs for here. As far as the stranded cost number, we will work those costs out through the system. I think the good news is what we've learned in the last separation was how to do this and how to do it efficiently. So I would just say on the stranded cost piece, if I look at project planning and what have you, we have that much more clearly defined. We know who owns it, and we know how that's going to come out of the system and when that comes out of the system.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And also that I think there's a real benefit to having done one separation. The first time you do it, you get the best advice you can and you learn how to do it. This time, we have this thing down to a science. And so I think a number of the same peo
componenttext: Yes. And also that I think there's a real benefit to having done one separation. The first time you do it, you get the best advice you can and you learn how to do it. This time, we have this thing down to a science. And so I think a number of the same people are going to work on this separation. And I'm highly confident we're going to be able to work off those stranded costs, probably faster than we did in Version 1.0.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And as my follow-up, Tim, on normalized free cash flow, given the higher transactional nature of the business post-ES, I'm a little surprised you have a fairly tight range of 3.5 to 3.8, if I heard you right. How should we think about the vol
componenttext: Okay, great. And as my follow-up, Tim, on normalized free cash flow, given the higher transactional nature of the business post-ES, I'm a little surprised you have a fairly tight range of 3.5 to 3.8, if I heard you right. How should we think about the volatility of that number? And then just longer term, normalize CapEx spend for HPE in a post-ES world.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me just clarify, the 3.5 to 3.8, that was '16 with ES in it. So if you're looking to pull ES out from a normalized perspective, that's not what I was talking about. I was talking about sort of our current guide with current separation, current re
componenttext: Yes, let me just clarify, the 3.5 to 3.8, that was '16 with ES in it. So if you're looking to pull ES out from a normalized perspective, that's not what I was talking about. I was talking about sort of our current guide with current separation, current restructuring, what have you. In general, if you strip out ES, I think about, obviously, ES has more CapEx than the other businesses. From a normalized CapEx perspective, I think you could see our CapEx go down by $500 million or $600 million. That's what we typically use for ES. So that's sort of how I think about it from a normalized perspective. Again, we'll give some more color when we do SAM in October, but I think CapEx is a big driver.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: As I said, I think what we are doing by the announcements we made today is unlocking the value of these 2 companies. And remember, EG plus Software plus our Financial Services business is a faster-growing, higher-margin, more robust free cash flow busines
componenttext: As I said, I think what we are doing by the announcements we made today is unlocking the value of these 2 companies. And remember, EG plus Software plus our Financial Services business is a faster-growing, higher-margin, more robust free cash flow business. And I think now that with a super-focused mission, we're going to see some real benefits there. And then, obviously, by consolidating CSC with ES, I think we're going to get real cost synergies there.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Simona Jankowski at Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: The next question is from Simona Jankowski at Goldman Sachs.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just the last question then on the fundamentals that you're seeing out there. It sounded like you attribute the strong performance in EG mostly to share gains. But can you also comment on the demand environment? And then just relative to those share
componenttext: Maybe just the last question then on the fundamentals that you're seeing out there. It sounded like you attribute the strong performance in EG mostly to share gains. But can you also comment on the demand environment? And then just relative to those share gains, you touched a little bit on what drove that, such as retooling the sales force, et cetera. Can you just comment in a little bit more detail on any other factors driving your success there, whether it's related to solution selling or pricing or products, anything of that nature?

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So listen, it is an uneven macroeconomic environment. I think Tim said that at first. And so different countries sort of go up and down different regions. But overall, I think we feel very comfortable with our position in the traditional IT market a
componenttext: Sure. So listen, it is an uneven macroeconomic environment. I think Tim said that at first. And so different countries sort of go up and down different regions. But overall, I think we feel very comfortable with our position in the traditional IT market and then in our ability to provide solutions in a multicloud environment. So I think demand can go up and down, but our objective is in whatever the market's doing, we want to make sure we at least hold or gain share, and we did that in the last quarter. And I don't think there's anything new to add as to why. First of all, I think the R&D investments that we've made over the last 4 years are paying off. So the development cycle in servers, storage, networking, those kinds of things, hyperconverged. These are long-term investments. What you started 3 years ago actually comes to the market now or even next year. So that investment in R&D is paying off. And I will tell you, $1 spent on internal R&D is the best dollar we spend at HP. It's fantastic. Second is when you retool a sales force, that takes some time as well. And I would say we're much farther along than we have been, and there is more work to do. And then, as I said, marketing, we've retooled our entire demand generation. We've retooled -- and by the way, the launch of Hewlett Packard Enterprise gave us a chance to tell people the story of the enterprise side of this business because, prior to that, if you had asked a man on the street what is HP, they'd say a printing and PC company. So I think that's actually been beneficial. And then turnarounds take 5 years. I said it when I started, and we're rounding the bend into the end of the fifth year. And so it's gratifying that we saw as-reported growth for the first time in 5 years.

headline: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, May 24, 2016
